LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Socialist Republic of Viet Nam

The  program  loan  will  support  implementation  of  the  Poverty 
Reduction  Program  outlined  under  the  development  partner-
funded Sixth Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC 6), as part 
of  the  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDP)  2006–2010  of 
the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  (the  Government).  The  SEDP 
provides a medium-term framework for this 5-year cycle of PRSC 
operations  that  comprises  poverty  reduction  policies,  programs, 
and  actions  with  specific  targets  for  development  outcomes  by 
2010.  
 
The  official  development  assistance  (ODA)  community  in  Viet 
Nam  considers  the  PRSC  to  be  an  important  instrument  for 
supporting  SEDP  implementation.  As  a  multisector  instrument 
covering a range of issues related to poverty reduction, the PRSC 
framework  provides  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  with  an 
opportunity  to (i) advance and widen the national policy dialogue 
in  a  well-coordinated  and  comprehensive  manner,  (ii)  provide 
lending and nonlending assistance in coordination with other ODA 
partners,  and  (iii)  ensure  that  key  policy  issues  affecting  ADB 
operations  in  Viet  Nam  are  addressed  in  the  policy  dialogue 
between  the  Government  and  the  ODA  community  to  help 
achieve the common goal of poverty reduction and growth.  
 
In addition to ADB, the World Bank and other major ODA partners 
intend  to  contribute  both  financial  and  intellectual  resources  to 
PRSC  6.  ODA  partners  include  Australia,  Canada,  Denmark,  the 
the 
European  Commission,  Germany, 
Netherlands,  Spain,  and  the  United  Kingdom.  Switzerland,  while 
not a financing partner, provided financial support for coordinating 
the  process.  The  International  Monetary  Fund,  France,  and  the 
United  Nations  Development  Programme  participated  in  the 
PRSC policy dialogue.

Impact and Outcome 

 
Cost Estimates 

The current cycle of PRSCs is a vehicle for the donor community 
to  stay  engaged  with  Viet  Nam,  and  has  delivered  outstanding 
performance in terms of economic growth and poverty reduction in 
the  previous  cycle.  The  PRSC  is  the  only  instrument  that  allows 
donors to actively engage in supporting a comprehensive, cross-
cutting  reform  agenda  in  Viet  Nam.  The  coherence  of  the 
comprehensive reform program under the PRSCs, particularly the 
fundamental governance reforms, helps ensure  the effectiveness 
of sectoral interventions by ADB and other donors. Both economic 
growth and changes in the social environment have occurred at a 
rapid  pace  in  recent  years,  and  active  and  frequent  engagement 
through PRSCs should help improve the content of specific policy 
actions, ensure their timely adoption, and assist in monitoring the 
impact of the overall program on broader development outcomes.   
 
ADB  has  been  actively  involved  in  formulating  PRSC  6,  and  has 
promoted  policy  dialogue  on  similar  issues  through  its  program 
lending activities and sector policy reforms. PRSC 6 complements 
ADB’s support of Viet Nam’s policy and institutional reforms.  
 
The  proposed  loan  adheres  to  ADB’s  recent  efforts  to  adopt 
program-based  and  sector  approaches  in  its  lending  operations, 
so  as  to  reduce  transaction  costs,  both  for  developing  member 
countries and its own operations. The approach is consistent with 
ADB’s  reform  agenda, 
framework,  and 
medium-term strategies I and II, and will directly help fulfill ADB’s 
obligations to the Rome Declaration on harmonizing procedures of 
multilateral  development  banks  (2003)  and  the  Paris  Declaration 
on Aid Effectiveness (2005). 
 
The  expected  impact  of  the  proposed  loan  is  to  reduce  poverty 
and  sustain  high  economic  growth  in  Viet  Nam.  The  proposed 
loan  will  help  fund  PRSC  6  and  thereby  (i)  reduce  structural 
weaknesses  and  improve  the  business  environment,  (ii)  promote 
social inclusion, (iii) protect natural resources, and (iv) modernize 
governance. 
 
Some  of  the  reforms  supported  by  the  PRSC  process  entail 
substantial  costs  to  be  financed  by  the  state.  Policy  measures 
supported by the PRSC operations require additional spending.  
 
The  estimated  cost  of  some  specific  PRSC-related  measures  for 
the  PRSC  6  implementation  period  is  approximately  $1,420 
million, i.e.,  (i)  health care  funds  for  the poor—about  $90  million, 
(ii) 
the 
Government  budget—about  $540  million,  (iii)  social  safety  net 
(SOE) 
program 
workers—about  $100  million,  and  (iv)  state-owned  commercial 
bank (SOCB) recapitalization—about $690 million.

Loan Amount and Terms  A  loan  equivalent  to  $15  million  in  special  drawing  rights  from 
ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  will  be  provided.  The  loan  will 
have  a  24-year  term  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years,  an 
interest rate of 1.0% during the grace period and 1.5% during the 
amortization period, and such other terms and conditions set forth 
in  the  draft  loan  agreement.  The  loan  proceeds  may  be  used  to 
finance eligible imports incurred within 180 days prior to the date 
of  loan  effectiveness.  The  loan  reflects  ADB’s  support  for 
implementation of the SEDP following the policy framework of the 
PRSC 6 program. The loan will contribute to financing adjustment 
costs  resulting  from  implementation  of  the  policy  matrix  and  will 
support and  facilitate the Government’s continued and deepened 
reform program for poverty reduction. 
 
The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon declaration of 
loan effectiveness. 
 
The loan will be fully utilized by 31 December 2008. 
 
The State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV) will be the Executing Agency. 
SBV works in close collaboration with the World Bank to prepare 
and implement the PRSCs.

The Steering Committee was established in June 2007 to advise 
the 
the  Prime  Minister 
Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy  and 
Poverty  Reduction  Support  Credits  in  consistence  with  the 
purposes  of  the  Scioeconomic  Development  Plan  2006–2010., 
Such committee is chaired by the deputy prime minister in charge 
of  economic  reforms,  and  consists  of  representatives  from 
relevant line ministries and government agencies. An SBV deputy 
governor  and  a  vice  minister  of  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and 
Investment  act  as  the  standing  vice  chairpersons.  To  represent 
PRSC  policy  reform  areas,  the  steering  committee  has  several 
representatives from key economic ministries (e.g., the ministries 
of  agriculture  and  rural  development;  education  and  training; 
finance;  foreign  affairs;  justice;  industry  and  trade;  and  labor, 
invalids,  and  social  affairs;  and),  as  well  as  the  Office  of  the 
Government. 
 
The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign 
exchange  costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items 
produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding 
ineligible  items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral  sources.  In  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  ADB’s 
Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements  for  Program  Loans,  the  proceeds  of  the  program 
loan will be disbursed to Viet Nam as the Borrower.  
 
No supporting import documentation will be required, provided the 
value of Viet Nam’s total imports minus imports from nonmember 
countries,  ineligible  imports,  and  imports  financed  under  other 
official  development  assistance  is  equal  to  or  greater  than  the 
amount  of  the  loan  expected  to  be  disbursed.  The  Government 
will  certify  its  compliance  with  this  formula  with  its  withdrawal 
request.  Otherwise, 
import  documentation  under  existing 
procedures  will  be  required.  ADB  will  have  the  right  to  audit  the 
use of loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the Borrower's 
certification.  As  such,  the  procedures  for  procurement  and 
disbursement of funds, and the use of counterpart funds, are felt 
to be satisfactory.

loan  will 

The  proposed  loan  will  benefit  the  Vietnamese  people  in  four 
ways. First, through policy actions designed to facilitate business 
development, 
increase  efficiency,  accelerate 
economic  growth,  and  create  jobs.  These  policy  actions  will  help 
improve the regulatory framework for private sector development, 
and  enhance  transparency  and  accountability  in  SOE  operations 
and in banking. Second, policy actions addressing social inclusion 
will  result  in  benefits  that  include  improved  quality  of  education, 
improved access of the poor to health services, a reformed social 
protection  system,  and  promotion  of  gender  equality.  Third, 
through policy actions addressing natural resources, the loan will 
help  secure  land  ownership  and  address  the  resettlement  and 
compensation  process,  as  well  as  promoting  more  sustainable 
management  of  natural  resources.  Fourth,  through  policy  actions 
increased 
addressing  modern  governance,  benefits 
transparency  and accountability of  public finances, and improved 
legal  transparency  and  accessibility.  These  will  be  achieved 
through better coordination of plans and budgets, adoption of the 
medium-term  expenditure  framework,  and  greater  accountability 
in public finance and public administration.  
 
There  are  three  potential  risks  associated  with  imbalances  that 
may emerge as Viet Nam achieves greater global integration and 
market-orientation.  
 
The first potential risk is the vulnerability that stems from possible 
turbulence in the financial sector. The supervisory and regulatory 
capacity  of  monetary  authorities  has  not  kept  pace  with  the 
expansion  of  capital  markets.  The  second  risk  relates  to  the 
massive  inflows  of  foreign  direct  investment  and  increased 
competition  in  formerly  protected  sectors.  This  change  may  test 
the ability of Viet Nam to preserve social inclusion, and may cause 
some  groups  to  lose  in  the  short  term.  The  third  possible  risk 
involves  potential  corruption  and  social  strife  related  to  rapid 
urbanization and infrastructure development.  
 
The Government is aware of  the potential risks, and will mitigate 
these by considering and implementing appropriate measures and 
proactive programs during program implementation.  
 
ADB,  along  with  other  PRSC  financing  partners,  has  conducted 
analytical  studies  to  help  policymakers  formulate  and  execute 
mitigating  and  corrective  measures  in  anticipation  of  these 
potential 
risks.  These  corrective  measures  have  been 
incorporated  in  the  series  of  PRSCs,  which  include  this  program 
loan.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
1. 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Support  the  Implementation  of  the  Poverty 
Reduction Program IV (SIPRP IV). The program loan follows a program-based approach and is 
part  of  the  Sixth  Poverty  Reduction  Support  Credit  (PRSC  6),  jointly  processed  by  several 
development  partners,  in  support  of  implementation  by  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  (the 
Government)  of  the  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDP)  2006–2010.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework for the program loan is in Appendix 1.  
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

2. 
Over the last 20 years, Viet Nam’s economy has been  transformed significantly. It has 
become  one  of  the  fastest-growing  economies  in  Asia,  recording  average  annual  gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth of 7.5% over the last decade. GDP per capita increased from 
$288  in  1993  to  $716  in  2006,  with  marginal  increase  in  inequality.  At  the  same  time,  the 
poverty incidence in the country declined sharply, from about 58.0% in 1993, to 28.9% in 2002, 
and 19.5% in 2004 (see Table A2.1 in Appendix 2).  
 
3. 
Economic  growth  in  Viet  Nam  has  been  largely  equitable.  Expenditure  inequality  (as 
measured  by  Gini  coefficient)  has  increased  only  marginally  during  the  1990s.  Nonetheless, 
some  groups  have  benefited  less  and  are  vulnerable  to  social  and  economic  marginalization. 
These  include  people  living  with  low  levels  of  human  capital,  ethnic  minorities,  and  to  some 
extent,  women.  Social  indicators  (such  as  school  enrollment  and  health  care)  are  lower  for 
these groups. Low-income households face a vicious cycle of remaining poor due to difficulties 
in accessing health and education services, especially if user fees are involved.1 There are also 
considerable  disparities  in  poverty  and  poverty  reduction  across  regions.  The  northern 
mountains,  the  north  central  coast,  and  the  central  highlands  all  have  high  poverty  incidence 
rates (over 30%), which are substantially higher than in other regions. These regions are home 
to nearly 57% of the total poor population.2  
 
4. 
The  impressive  outcomes  of  simultaneous  continuing  high  economic  growth  and  rapid 
poverty  reduction  were  achieved  through  a  combination  of  sustained  business-led  growth  in 
economic output and employment and government-led targeted poverty reduction interventions. 
The  latter  include,  for  example,  programs  focusing  on  (i)  hunger  eradication  and  poverty 
reduction (Program 143); (ii) socioeconomic development in communes with extreme difficulties 
(Program 135); (iii) heath care for the poor (Program 139); (iv) compensation for job losses due 
to state enterprise reform (Social  Safety Net Fund); (v)  schooling at all levels, including adult-
and-non-formal,  and  life-long  learning  (Education  for  All);  and  (vi)  helping    ethnic  minorities 
catch up with the overall socioeconomic development (Advancing Ethnic Minorities). Viet Nam’s 
transition from central planning to a socialist-oriented market economic system has involved the 
liberalization of markets, recognition of private property rights, and a gradual opening up of the 
economy  to  external  markets  for  trade  and  investment.  The  growth  of  the  private  sector  has 
been a significant feature of economic development. The structure of the economy is changing 
markedly, with a steady increase in the industrial and service sectors. Greater diversification in 
industrial production and services is laying  the  foundations  for sustained growth in output and 
employment.

 2 

A. 

Development Objectives, Strategies, and Plans 

The Government of Viet Nam is committed to poverty reduction and considers it to be an 
5. 
overarching  objective  in  its  national  socioeconomic  development  process.  Evidence  of  the 
Government’s commitment includes a series of strategic plans and documents, including the 10-
Year Socioeconomic Development Strategy 2001–2010, the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction 
and  Growth  Strategy  (CPRGS)  2002–2006,  the  5-Year  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan 
(SEDP)  2001–2005,  and  SEDP  2006–2010.  The  SEDP  2006–2010  is  considered  Viet  Nam’s 
national strategy for poverty reduction and growth, which articulates the vision for Viet Nam to 
attain middle-income status by 2010. The SEDP is recognized as a blueprint for development, 
because  it  is  based  on  empirical  analysis  and  broad  consultation,  and  identifies  clear 
development  outcomes,  specifies  policies  to  attain  its  goals,  and  aligns  public  resources  to 
implement these policies.  
 
Viet  Nam’s  development  strategy  is  embodied  in  the  SEDP  2006–2010,  which  was 
6. 
endorsed by the National Assembly in June 2006. The SEDP is expected to be Viet Nam’s new 
national  strategy  for  poverty  reduction  and  growth.  Reducing  poverty  incidence  to  10–11%  by 
2010  is  an  overarching  goal  of  the  SEDP  2006–2010.  Its  aims  include,  among  others,  to  (i) 
accelerate  and  sustain  economic  growth  and  development;  (ii)  significantly  improve  people’s 
material,  cultural,  and  spiritual  life;  (iii)  create  the  foundations  to  boost  industrialization  and 
modernization  and  to  gradually  develop  a  knowledge-based  economy;  and  (iv)  enhance  Viet 
Nam’s  status  in  the  region  and  the  world.  The  SEDP  has  a  strong  results-orientation,  with 
performance  indicators  that  include  the  Viet  Nam  Development  Goals  (VDGs)  and  the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). The SEDP was prepared in an intensively participatory 
and  consultative  manner  with  substantive  inputs  from  a  broad  range  of  interest  groups.  The 
main targets are specified to ensure sustainable development across the economy, society, and 
environment.  
 
7. 
In  the SEDP,  the  Government embraces reform actions  that  fall broadly into  four  main 
areas: (i) the promotion of growth and transition to a market economy; (ii) reducing poverty and 
ensuring social inclusion; (iii) managing the environment and natural resources in a sustainable 
manner;  and  (iv)  building  institutions  that  can  support  the  strategy.  The  first  three  pillars  are 
explicitly  listed  in  the  SEDP,  while  the  fourth  is  introduced  in  the  monitoring  and  evaluation 
(M&E) framework. The fourth pillar is recognized as the foundation for making progress on the 
first  three.  Intended  reform  actions  under  the  four  pillars  will  be  carried  out  with  the  goal  of 
achieving middle-income status by end-2010. The Asian Development Bank (ADB), World Bank 
and  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP)  have  helped  develop  the  results-
framework  and  M&E  framework  of  the  Government’s  SEDP  in  close  collaboration  with  other 
development  partners.  Appendix  2  presents  details  on  the  SEDP  in  the  context  of  PRSC 
operations.  
 
8. 
The Government and development partners realize that the impressive gains in poverty 
reduction  realized  to  date  remain  fragile.  In  addition,  achieving  further  poverty  reductions  will 
become  increasingly  difficult,  as  gains  will  be  harder  to  realize  among  more  marginalized 
groups. Providing services to rural poor and ethnic minorities who live in remote areas requires 
more marginal resources. To help the poor in mountainous areas increase land use productivity, 
especially productivity of forest land, the Government revised the Law on Forest Protection and 
Development  in  2004  and  issued  the  related  Forest  Development  Strategy  (2006–2010)  in 
February  2007,  providing  guidance  on  moving  toward  more  social  and  community-based 
forestry. The strategy recognizes the forest-use rights of households and communities and their 

  

3 

ownership  of  plantation  forests.  The  issuance  of  such  strategies  is  one  of  the  policy  actions 
proposed in this program loan.  
  
9. 
An  additional  factor  complicating  future  poverty  reduction  is  the  large  number  of  the 
near-poor. A significant proportion of the population was just below the poverty line in 1993, and 
had barely moved above the poverty line by 1998; they remain vulnerable to shocks that could 
push  them  back  below  the  poverty  line.  Future  challenges  include  (i)  allocating  additional 
resources, (ii) the ability to mobilize external resources, (iii) improved targeting of resources, (iv) 
enhanced  efficiency  by  making  social  services  more  demand  driven,  and  (v)  improved 
monitoring systems that ensure benefits actually reach the poor. 
 
10. 
Viet  Nam  became  a  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  member  in  January  2007,  and 
further  integration  of  Viet  Nam’s  economy  into  the  global  and  regional  economy  will  help 
stimulate  structural  reforms  and  open  access  to  markets,  capital  and  technology,  resulting  in 
higher economic productivity. Globalization and regional integration bring opportunities but also 
challenges,  including  for  groups  employed  by  enterprises  that  are  no  longer  competitive,  and 
which consequently lose their jobs. The SEDP 2006–2010 has shifted the focus of priority areas 
from  basic  structural  reforms  to  more  complex  issues—including  building  inclusive  and 
financially viable social insurance systems—so as to respond to the needs of those negatively 
impacted  by  global  integration  in  the  short  term.  The  National  Assembly  passed  the  Social 
Insurance Law in November 2006, which is one of the policy actions under this program loan. 
Other  priorities  of  the  SEDP  2006–2010,  which  are  also  priorities  of  the  PRSC  operations, 
include  (i)  strengthening  the  supervision  of  financial  markets,  (ii)  regulating  access  to  and 
pricing  of  infrastructure  services,  (iii)  managing  natural  resources  and  protecting  environment, 
and (iv) increasing transparency and accountability at all levels.  
 
B. 
 
11. 
Viet Nam is one of the fastest-growing economies in Asia, recording an average annual 
growth  in  GDP  of  about  7.5%  over  the  last  decade.  Underpinned  by  rapid  growth  in  private 
investment,  strong  consumption  and  robust  exports,  GDP  growth  accelerated  to  8%  for  2006 
and  an  estimated  8.3%  for  2007,3 above  its  trend  rate  of  the  last  10  years.  Demand  for  the 
country’s  exports  of  commodities,  crude  oil,  and  manufactures  was  strong,  and  private 
investment  and  private  consumption  also  recorded  robust  growth.  Growth 
in  private 
consumption  was  supported  by  rising  incomes  and  inward  remittances  of  about  $4  billion  in 
2006.    Increasing  consumption  is  partly  a  result  of  favorable  demographics,  as  Viet  Nam  has 
one of youngest populations in Asia, with more than 65% of  the population below 30 years of 
age. Retail sales of goods and services increased by 20.9% in 2006 (about 13% after adjusting 
for inflation), higher than the 16.9% average recorded over the previous 5 years.  
 
12. 
Exports  performed  strongly  in  2006,  rising  by  23.0%  in  nominal  US  dollar  terms, 
compared  with  average  annual  growth  of  17%  from  2001–2005.  The  ratio  of  exports  to  GDP 
increased  from  about  55%  in  2000  to  66%  in  2006,  indicating  the  openness  of  the  economy 
even before Viet Nam joined the  WTO in January 2007. The structure  of exports is becoming 
more diversified; while unprocessed commodities such as crude oil, rice, marine products, and 
agriculture  products  remain  important,  the  share  of  manufactured  products  is  rising.  Robust 
domestic demand, particularly from investment projects, caused imports to grow by 33.3%. As a 
consequence, the trade deficit was estimated at $4.5 billion, equivalent to 8.7% of GDP in 2006. 
Vigorous  expansion  in  both  private  remittances  and  tourism  receipts  helped  limit  the  current 

Recent Economic Performance 

                                                 
3 ADB. 2007.  Asian Development Outlook Update. Manila. 

 

 

 4 

account deficit to $1.26 billion, or 2.1% of GDP in 2006. Buoyant foreign direct investment (FDI) 
inflows supported the balance of payments, resulting in a rise in gross international reserves to 
$11.5 billion, equivalent to 3.5 months of imports in 2006.  
 
13. 
From the production side, the industry and services sectors contributed more than 90% 
of total GDP growth in 2006. Industry expanded by a robust 10.4%, slightly below the pace in 
2005. The services sector, supported by buoyant performance in trade, tourism, transportation, 
telecommunications,  and  financial  services,  grew  by  an  estimated  8.2%,  higher  than  the 
average of 2001–2005. Inflation remained high, exceeding 7% on average during 2006 for the 
third year in a row. The high inflation rate was mainly a result of a jump in food prices caused by 
strong  demand.  However,  the  inflation  rate  is  projected  to  decrease  in  2007  and  2008  due  to 
reduced tariff rates following WTO accession, and expected reductions in crude oil prices in the 
world market.  
 
The overall fiscal deficit remained high in 2006 at 5.0% of GDP, slightly above the 4.8% 
14. 
average  of  the  last  five  years  so  as  to  finance  the  required  infrastructure  investment.  Fiscal 
revenues surpassed the planned target by 10%. Total revenue (excluding grants) stands at 24% 
of GDP. This increase was attributable to higher oil revenues (accounting for about 29% of total 
revenue),  improvements  in  tax  administration,  and  the  growing  number  of  tax-paying 
businesses in the formal sector. Off-budget expenditures rose from 1.2% of GDP in 2004 to an 
estimated  2%  of  GDP  in  2006.  These  are  mainly  used  for  investment  in  infrastructure  and 
education. Investment in infrastructure now exceeds 9% of GDP and is expected to reach 11% 
in  coming  years.  Off-budget  expenditures  are  subject  to  the  same  scrutiny  by  the  National 
Assembly as is budgetary spending.  
 
15. 
 Viet  Nam  is  a  moderately-indebted  country.  At  the  end  of  2006,  public  and  publicly-
guaranteed  debt  was  an  estimated  45.5%  of  GDP  in  nominal  terms.  External  debt  was 
estimated at around 32% of GDP. In 2006, total debt servicing is estimated at 5.6%, down from 
6.7% in 2004. Viet Nam’s external debt indicators remained below the applicable threshold.

16. 
Under the baseline scenario of the International Monetary Fund- (IMF) World Bank debt 
sustainability assessment, public and publicly guaranteed debt is projected to increase slightly, 
from about 41% of GDP in 2004 to around 43% in 2009, before stabilizing. In net present value 
terms, the debt increases from 28% of GDP in 2004 to about 29% of GDP and stabilizes over 
the long term. The main risk to medium-term debt sustainability stems from contingent liabilities 
associated  with  reform  of  state-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCBs).  Given  the  uncertainty 
surrounding bank balance sheets, the debt sustainability assessment considers two alternative 
reform  scenarios,  associated  with  contingent  liabilities  of  8%  and  20%  of  GDP.  In  these  two 
scenarios, the net present value of public debt reaches peaks of 35% and 49% of GDP before 
declining  to  30%  and  33%  over  the  long  term.  The  assessment  will  be  updated  in  the  third 
quarter  of  2006  to  reflect  the  impact  of  the  investment  program  contemplated  in  the  SEDP 
2006–2010. In addition, IMF has provided a letter of assessment (Appendix 3).  
 

III. 

THE SECTOR 

A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

1. 

Progress in Reducing Poverty 

17. 
In aggregate terms Viet Nam’s rapid progress in reducing poverty is unprecedented. No 
other country has reduced poverty incidence so much in such a short time.4 Data from the four 
Viet Nam Household Living Standards Surveys (VHLSSs) conducted in 1993, 1998, 2002, and 
2004  reveal  that  Viet  Nam  has  achieved  remarkable  success  in  poverty  reduction  during  the 
period  of  1993–2004;  the  poverty  rate,  as  measured  by  per  capita  consumption,  has  dropped 
almost  39  percentage  points  over  this  11-year  period.  The  poverty  rate  in  2004  was  one-third 
the  1993  rate,  meaning  Viet  Nam  outperformed  the  United  Nations’  Millennium  Development 
Goal  of  halving  extreme  poverty  over  a  25-year  period  (1990  to  2015).  The  pace  at  which 
poverty rates have fallen has accelerated remarkably over the last few years. The poverty gap5 
indicates that those who are still in poverty are becoming less poor. In 1993, consumption of the 
average poor person was equal to 68% of the poverty line; by 2004, it had climbed to 76%. The 
remarkable performance in terms of income and expenditure is also supported by outstanding 
social indicators: improvements in the net enrollment rate, health insurance coverage, access to 
electricity, clean water, sanitation, and possession of numerous durable goods reflect significant 
improvements in people’s wellbeing. During this period relative inequality, as measured by the 
Gini index for per capita expenditures, has shown a modest increase, from 0.33 in 1993 to 0.37 
in 2004. This is comparable to other countries at a similar level of development.  
 
18.  When poverty and inequality are examined at  disaggregate levels, however, significant 
variation  in  progress  in  poverty  reduction  can  be  seen  across  different  segments  of  society. 
Although declines in poverty  have  been achieved  in all major segments of society, the rate of 
decline has been slower in (i) rural areas than in urban areas, (ii) among most ethnic minority 
groups in comparison to the majority group, and (iii) in some regions than in others. Poverty has 
become  largely  a  rural  phenomenon.  Three  out  of  eight  regions6 of  the  country  have  suffered 

                                                 
4  Between 1990 and 2004, the percentage of the population living in poverty in Viet Nam fell by roughly 3 percentage 
points per year, or twice the rate of the People’s Republic of China (when measured by the benchmark of $1 per 
day, adjusted by purchasing power parity).  

5  The poverty gap measures the depth of poverty. It shows the shortfall from the poverty line of expenditure by the 

poor, expressed as an average of all people in the population.  

6  The eight regions of Viet Nam comprise the northeast, the northwest, Red River Delta, north central coast, south 
central  coast,  central  highlands,  southeast,  and  the  Mekong  River  Delta.  The  first  two  regions  combined  are 
considered the northern mountainous region.  

 

 

 6 

most, with high poverty incidence and a poverty rate (in 2004) over 30%. In addition, the rate of 
poverty  reduction  has  varied  considerably  across  regions  from  1993  to  2004.  The  pace  of 
poverty  reduction  has  been  slowest  in  the  northwest,  and  this  region  remains  the  country’s 
poorest, with a persistently high poverty incidence of 59%. The 2004 survey suggests that the 
north  central  coast  has  the  largest  pocket  of  poverty,  followed  by  the  northeast,  the  Mekong 
River Delta and the Red River Delta. Progress in poverty reduction among ethnic minorities is 
relatively limited. During the 11-year period, the poverty rate for ethnic minorities fell from 86% 
to 61%, while the poverty rate for the majority Kinh-Hoa group fell from 54% to 14%. There is 
also  significant  underperformance  by  ethnic  minorities  compared  to  the  majority  group  with 
regard  to  social  indicators.  Regional  and  ethnic  disparities  may  be  explained  by  the 
disadvantaged living position of those involved, and a lack of regional convergence (footnote 2). 
 
19. 
An understanding of the factors responsible for past achievements in poverty reduction 
would  provide  guidance  for  future  policy  interventions.  There  is  consensus  that  poverty 
reduction  has  been  underpinned  by  rapid,  stable  and  inclusive  economic  growth.7 A  series  of 
far-reaching  market  reforms  undertaken  in  the  1990s  and  early  2000s  has  resulted  in 
improvements  in  the  geographic  and  occupational  mobility  of  labor,  enabling  people  to  take 
advantage  of  better  income-generating  opportunities.  The  relatively  pro-poor  pattern  of  public 
investments and budget transfers, including national poverty-targeting programs (i.e., Program 
135 and Program 143) has led to improved access by the poor to education, health care, and 
infrastructure.  Another  important  element  of  the  rapid  poverty  reduction  has  been  the 
redistribution of agricultural land to rural households. The allocation of land-use right certificates 
(LUCs) to lowland rural households amounted to a massive and egalitarian transfer of wealth. 
This  resulted  in  a  dramatic  increase  in  agricultural  production  and  exports,  and  effectively 
helped  millions  of  households  escape  poverty.  The  three  preceding  loans  (SIPRP  I,  II  and  III 
under  the  PRSC  3–5  framework)  have  included  these  critical  policy  reforms.  Political  stability 
and  broad-based  growth  in  economic  output  and  employment  also  underpinned  poverty 
reduction. 
  
20. 
There  are  also  reasons  to  believe  that  Viet  Nam’s  future  experience  with  poverty  may 
differ  somewhat  from  what  has  occurred  in  the  past.  The  current  distribution  of  incomes  and 
expenditures  implies  that  a  higher  growth  rate  is  required  to  achieve  a  one-percentage-point 
drop in poverty.  This calls for  further  strengthening of  the  existing national  targeting programs 
on  poverty  reduction.  In  addition,  the  relatively  large  number  of  non-poor  people  whose 
consumption is just above the poverty line level implies that protecting vulnerable people from 
falling back into poverty is becoming increasingly important for the reduction of overall poverty. 
Particularly, vulnerable groups are now facing various shocks—including communicable disease 
outbreaks,  natural disasters, and sharp dips in global agricultural commodity prices—and may 
face these again in the future. The persistently high poverty incidence and depth among ethnic 
minority groups and some lagging regions is a big challenge for Viet Nam in the next five years. 
In addition, new forms of poverty will emerge, caused in part by the process of urbanization. 
 
 In light of these challenges, sustaining rapid poverty reduction over the next five years 
21. 
will  require  a  combination  of  policy  measures,  including  an  acceleration  of  market-oriented 
reforms, and in particular an emphasis on development of the private sector to achieve higher 
efficiency. This would permit more rapid growth within resource constraints, as growth continues 
to be a main driver of poverty reduction. Innovative measures should also be used to enhance

associated  with  a  reduction  in  poverty  of  about  7%  for  1993–2002  (Vietnam  Development  Report  2004  and 
Vietnam Poverty Update Report 2006).

2.  

The Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010  

participation by the poor in economic growth. In addition, priority should be given to revamping 
and  strengthening  social  protection  mechanisms,  including  universal  systems  that  can  better 
protect  the  poor  and  vulnerable  from  adverse  shocks,  in  light  of  intensified  international 
integration.  
 
22. 
Various additional measures are required in addition to the current schemes supporting 
ethnic  minorities.  These  include  (i)  more  unified  control  over  forest  land  under  the  district  and 
commune authorities and (ii) improved transparency and equity in allocation of forest land and 
product usage rights. There is also a need for other innovative measures and interventions that 
better address the needs of the most disadvantaged ethnic minority groups and better take into 
account their specific habits, customs, and culture.  
 
 
 
The  SEDP  was  finalized  and  approved  by  the  National  Assembly  in  June  2006.  The 
23. 
SEDP  was  prepared  with  support  of  the  development  assistance  community,  including  ADB, 
and  in  consultation  with  stakeholders  and  civil  society  (Appendix  2).  Implementation  of  the 
SEDP  policy  reform  agenda  has  been  undertaken  largely  through  the  Government’s  own 
resources, supplemented by pooling of ODA grant and lending resources under the PRSC 6–10 
framework. The PRSC framework was prepared by development partners in close consultation 
with government agencies. SEDP 2006–2010 includes open discussions about disadvantaged 
groups  and  regions  and  about  the  challenges  presented  by  the  emergence  of  a  growing  gap 
between  socioeconomic  groups.  Issues  of  social  inclusion  are  no  longer  restricted  to  the 
discussion of targeted programs but are instead tackled in the sectoral sections of the plan.  
 
24. 
The  Government  has  well-established  coordinating,  monitoring,  and  oversight 
arrangements for poverty reduction programs funded by various ODA resources. The Steering 
Committee  was  established  in  June  2007  to  advise  the  Prime  Minister  on  the  developing  and 
implementing  of  the  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy  and  Poverty 
Reduction  Support  Credits  in  accordance  to  the  purposes  of  the  SEDP  2006–2010.  Such 
steering committee is chaired by a deputy prime minister, with an SBV deputy governor and a 
vice minister of the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) as standing vice chairpersons. Its 
members  come  from  all  concerned  government  ministries  and  agencies.  The  steering 
committee guides implementation of the poverty reduction programs during PRSCs 6–10.8 The 
Government  undertakes  detailed  reviews  of  implementation  progress  of  the  PRSC  reform 
agenda, and discusses findings and emerging issues with its development assistance partners, 
usually at annual consultative group meetings.  
 
B. 

Issues and Opportunities 

1.  

Problem/Constraints Analysis 

 
 
The list of policy reforms considered by the SEDP 2006–2010 is remarkably broad. As 
25. 
this program loan and its subsequent loans will support implementation of the SEDP, it is critical 
to prioritize and sequence those reforms. Supporting the PRSC reform agenda, which is based 
on  the  SEDP  reform  agenda,  does  not  entail  favoring  one  of  the  four  pillars  over  the  others. 
Instead, balanced progress in all four pillars is critical for successful SEDP implementation. The 

                                                 
8  This new steering committee was established to replace the original National Steering Committee, established in 
2002 for the purpose of implementing the poverty reduction programs under the CPRGS during the implementation 
of PRSCs 1–5. 

 

 

 8 

prioritization and sequencing exercise should be carried out so as to be selective within each of 
the pillars. 

26. 
PRSC financing partners recognize that some of the needed reforms will be challenging, 
requiring  attention  to  their  content  and  timeliness.  In  addition,  the  more  complex  post-WTO 
accession  requires  strong  cross-sectoral  coordination  to  implement  WTO  commitments  from 
both  compliance  and  development  standpoints.  To  ensure  the  SEDP  is  a  sound  plan  that 
delivers  growth  while  reducing  poverty,  the  Government  needs  to  continue  its  prudent 
macroeconomic management and implement state sector reform without unnecessary delays.  
 
The policy actions under this PRSC were derived from a joint-donor analysis included in 
27. 
the Viet Nam Development Report (VDR) 2007 that was published in December 2006.9 A small-
scale technical assistance (TA) project (Support to the Implementation of the Poverty Reduction 
Program  II),  approved  on  9  June  2005,  assisted  in  improving  the  quality  of  formulation  and 
implementation  of  this  program  loan,  as  well  as  the  preceding  three  loans.  This  TA  provided 
resources to enhance the program’s compliance with safeguard policies. Through this TA, ADB 
also provided funding to organize a consultative workshop for the preparation of the VDR 2007 
(in  November  2006),  as  well  as  a  PRSC  process  review  workshop  (the  PRSC  Stocktaking 
Workshop held in October 2005). The policy actions under the subsequent PRSCs will also be 
refined  based  on  results  from  subsequent  analytical  VDRs  that  will  be  published  annually  for 
dissemination at year-end consultative group meetings. Repeating the analytical and dialoguing 
process undertaken in the PRSC series will help ensure the content and timing of the numerous 
reforms that spread across multiple sectors is appropriate. The active engagement will provide 
the  opportunity  for  all  stakeholders  to  identify  policy  actions  that  are  (i)  consistent  with 
nationally-owned  development  strategies  and  plans,  (ii)  sensible  from  an  economic  point  of 
view, (iii) capable of making a considerable difference in practice, and (iv) sufficiently specific to 
be adopted and implemented relatively quickly. 
 

2. 

Country Strategy and Program of the Asian Development Bank 

 
ADB’s goal is to help the Government reduce poverty incidence to 10–11% by 2010, in 
28. 
line  with  the  Government’s  vision  in  the  SEDP.  The  results-based  approach  adopted  by  the 
ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  (CSP)  for  Viet  Nam  2007–2010 10 is  directly  linked  to 
supporting the SEDP’s targeted outcomes. The CSP indicates that Viet Nam is now facing the 
challenge of improving its efficiency, as the investment to GDP ratio is already high by regional 
and  international  standards.  This  will  require  better  management  of  public  expenditure  and 
resources, including sustained efforts to control corruption. Increasing the private sector share 
of  total  investment  by  creating  an  enabling  environment  and  providing  infrastructure  will  also 
help increase investment efficiency and accelerate job creation.  
 
 ADB’s country poverty assessment,11 which provided analytical inputs to the preparation 
29. 
of both the CSP and the previous PRSC, indicated that although economic growth in Viet Nam 
has  benefited  most  of  society,  some  groups  have  benefited  less  than  others.  Poverty  incident

Lessons  

3. 

a. 

Lending Modality 

30. 
According  to  the  2001  special  evaluation  report  on  program  lending  by  the  Operations 
Evaluation  Department  (OED),  the  program’s  lending  modality  is  a  welcome  alternative  to 
typical  program  loans,  which  are  generally  limited  to  two-tranche  programs.  The  report 
recommended that multiple and floating tranches could effectively provide flexibility in meeting 
and  preserving  incentives  for  policy  changes,  in  remaining  engaged,  and  in  adopting  a  long-
term outlook.12 The innovative lending modality for the PRSCs is also referred to in the recent 
OED study Good Practices for the Evaluation of Policy-Based Lending by Multilateral Banks.13  
 
31.  While this program loan is processed as a single-tranche program loan, it is actually part 
of  a  multiple-tranche  program  loan  series  (PRSCs  6–10)  supporting  implementation  of  the 
SEDP  2006–2010.  The  lending  modality  for  the  PRSCs  is  (i)  based  in  part  on  past 
achievements,  in  that  all  policy  actions  have  been  achieved  before  loan  approval,  with  loan 
proceeds  to  be  disbursed  immediately  upon  loan  effectiveness,  to  finance  adjustment  costs 
arising  from  agreed  reforms;  and  (ii)  forward-looking,  in  that  each  annual  PRSC  contains 
agreements on policy triggers considered a critical bridge between the current and next PRSC. 
Policy triggers are policy reforming trends that are expected to evolve substantively during the 
subsequent PRSC. Policy triggers are not intended to be stated in the manner of conventional 
policy conditions, thus allowing for refinement of exact progress, according to the Government’s 
readiness to embark on such reform. (Appendix 2 indicates the policy areas considered critical 
for the next PRSC operation by PRSC stakeholders.) 
 
32. 
The  PRSCs  complement  rather  than  replace  other  initiatives  of  ADB,  the  World  Bank, 
and  other  development  partners.  They  complement  other  analytical  studies,  policy  dialogues, 
and  programs  and  projects,  and  vice  versa.  Following  ADB’s  participation  as  one  of  the 
financing partners to PRSCs 3, 4 and 5 in the first 5-year PRSC cycle, ADB has confirmed its 
plan to participate in the current cycle. The program loans to support PRSCs 6–10 are included 
in  the  country  strategy  and  program  for  2007–2010.  The  coexistence  of  ADB  sector-specific 
program  loans  and  the  PRSCs  is  seen  as  leveraging  ADB’s  development  efforts  in  Viet  Nam 
with  other  stakeholders.  PRSC  operations  also  provide  a  complementary  forum  to  aid 
harmonization in the country’s development agenda.

b. 

Lessons from Previous PRSC Cycles 

The  main  contribution  of  PRSCs  has  been  their  ability  to  serve  as  a  platform  for  a 
33. 
continued  policy  dialogue  with  key  government  counterparts  on  a  broad  range  of  issues. 
However,  given  the  encompassing  nature  of  Viet  Nam’s  reform  program  generally,  and  of  the 
CPRGS agenda in particular, progress was not even across all policy areas.  Identifying strong 
and weak areas in policy making is essential to ensure the sustainability of this effort over time. 
Starting  with  PRSC  3,  a  set  of  indicators  covering  a  broad  range  of  policy  areas  was  used  to 
assess progress, but these indicators may need revision. Both the previous 5-year plan and the 
CPRGS lacked a monitoring and evaluation framework, with indicators instead derived from the 
text of those documents and from other relevant sectoral strategies and policy statements. 
 
34. 
Overall, progress was slower in those policy areas characterized by limited political will, 
conflicting institutional responsibilities or insufficient analysis. The speed at which progress was 
made  across  policy  areas  within  each  pillar  depended  on  the  political  will  to  implement  the 
reforms.  The  contrast  between  the  rapid  progress  achieved  in  integrating  with  the  world 
economy and the slow pace of reform in the banking sector is revealing in this respect. To some 
extent,  this  contrast  may  reflect  a  deliberate  choice,  in  which  rapid  movement  towards  WTO 
accession  would  make  inevitable  the  need  for  subsequent  banking  sector  reforms.  In  other 
cases  (e.g.,  water)  limited  progress  reflects  institutional  overlap  and  unclear  delineation  of 
responsibility  across  several  ministries  or  agencies.  In  the  case  of  corruption,  there  is  an 
undeniable  commitment  to  battle  corruption,  but  it  is  recent,  and  in  such  instances  progress 
made on inputs (such as laws, or coordinating bodies) may take considerable time to translate 
into progress on outputs and outcomes. Specifics aside, when policy areas are classified on the 
basis  of  progress  the  results  are  consistent  with  the  ratings  prepared  for  the  country 
performance  assessment  (CPA).  Those  ratings  are  above  the  regional  average  in  relation  to 
macroeconomic  management  and  social  inclusion,  and  below  the  average  in  relation  to  the 
financial sector, labor and social protection, and transparency and anticorruption. 

35. 
Identification  and  sequencing  of  a  comprehensive  PRSC  reform  agenda  covering  the 
medium term requires strong analytical work. The VDR 2007, co-signed by 16 donors, provides 
the  main  analytical  underpinnings  for  the  current  5-year  PRSC  cycle.  The  preparation  of  this 
report,  entitled  Aiming  High,  started  shortly  after  approval  of  the  SEDP  by  the  National 
Assembly. The report was submitted to the consultative group meeting of December, 2006 as a 
contribution by the international community to implementation of the SEDP. The report built on 
the analytical work done over the previous PRSC cycle on structural reforms (as summarized in 
the  VDR  2006,  Business),  institutional  modernization  (VDR  2005,  Governance)  and  on  social 
inclusion  (VDR  2004,  Poverty).  ADB  has  actively  participated  in  formulating  VDR  2007  by 
contributing extensive written inputs and comments. Lessons from previous PRSCs and similar 
programs  suggest  that  conducting  joint  analytical  work  between  development  partners  is 
important, along with wide consultation with academia, civil society, and the Government. The 
development partners and academia can assist the Government in terms of analytical tools and 
sharing  of  international  experience.  The  multiple-tranche  program  loan  approach  could  be 
effective in  providing flexibility in meeting and preserving incentives for policy changes, and in 
maintaining  ongoing  engagement,  with  a  longer-term  outlook  than  the  usual  two-tranche 
program loan.  
 

c. 

Asian Development Bank Policy-Based Lending 

36. 
Lessons from the experience of previous program loans and postevaluation studies are 
that  (i)  continued  government  ownership  and  commitment  are  fundamental  to  achieving

and outputs) and outcome indicators; (iii) outcome indicators will depend on successful follow-

the  law  is  not  brought  into  effect  (which  requires  regulations,  circulars,  etc.),  and  (b)  properly 
enforced (requiring institutional capabilities); and (iv) sector or subsector-based program loans

4. 

Justification for the Sixth Poverty Reduction Support Credit  

the  business  environment,  (ii)  making  development  socially 

 
37. 
PRSC  6  addresses  three  key  areas  of  macro  policy  and  institutional  reforms  for  (i) 
supporting  the  transition  to  a  market  economy  by  removing  structural  weaknesses  and 
improving 
inclusive  and 
environmentally friendly, and (iii) modernizing governance and the public administration system. 
The  policy  actions  identified  in  the  PRSC  6  policy  matrix  are  built  on  the  reform  measures 
achieved  under  previous  PRSCs.  The  preparation  of  PRSC  6  was  built  on  the  strong 
commitment by the ODA community to (i) support Viet Nam’s reform agenda through nationwide 
implementation  of  the  SEDP,  and  (ii)  galvanize  interest  for  the  reform  program  among 
stakeholders.  Development  partners  have  increasingly  united  around  the  PRSC  as  an 
instrument for policy dialogue. They have been actively involved in supporting implementation of 
the reform agenda, analytical work, technical assistance, project lending, and program lending 
or  grant  support.  The  rationale  for  providing  financial  support  under  PRSC  6  comes  from  the 
external financing needed to cover the cost of reform adjustments. The policy actions supported 
by  the  PRSC  process—including  recapitalization  of  SOCBs,  operation  of  a  safety  net  for 
workers  who  become  redundant  as  a  result  of  SOE  restructuring,  expansion  of  budget 
appropriations  for  the  education  sector,  and  creation  of  provincial  health  care  funds  for  the 
poor—entail a substantial additional cost to the Government.  
 
38. 
Justification  for  PRSC  6  is  grounded  on  three  criteria:  (i)  prudent  macroeconomic 
management to ensure that progress on the long-term reform agenda will not be undermined by 
short-term instability; (ii) the Government’s own assessment of progress accomplished in SEDP 
implementation; and (iii) the strategic reform actions for PRSC 6, which were identified based on 
analytical input, and have been complied with.  
 
39. 
IMF’s  assessment  of  Viet  Nam’s  economic  performance  confirms  the  country’s 
impressive overall record of economic performance in 2006 and broadly favorable prospects for 
2007  (Appendix  3).  Based  on  the  joint  assessment  by  the  World  Bank  and  IMF,  the  SEDP  is 
fiscally  sustainable,  despite  the  high  level  of  investment  associated  with  the  development  of 
large-scale  infrastructure.  The  baseline  scenario  of  the  most  recent  debt  sustainability 
assessment (DSA) is broadly in line with the investment and growth outlook of the SEDP. The 
DSA estimates that public and publicly-guaranteed debt will increase from nearly 44% of GDP in 
2005 to about 51% by 2011. This increase is still considered manageable, as more than half will 
remain  on  highly  concessional  terms.  In  addition,  external  debt  (both  public  and  private)  is 
projected to decline from over 32% to under 31% of GDP. Viet Nam should thus remain at low 
risk of external debt distress.14

5. 

Rationale for the Proposed Program Loan 

 
40. 
The ODA community in Viet Nam considers the PRSC to be an important instrument for 
supporting  SEDP  implementation.  As  a  multisector  instrument  covering  a  range  of  issues 
related  to  poverty  reduction,  the  PRSC  framework  provides  ADB  with  an  opportunity  to  (i) 
advance  and  widen  the  national  policy  dialogue  in  a  well-coordinated  and  comprehensive 
manner; (ii) provide lending and nonlending assistance in coordination with other ODA partners; 
and (iii) ensure that key policy issues affecting ADB operations in Viet Nam are addressed in the 
policy dialogue between the Government and the ODA community, to help achieve the common 
goal of poverty reduction and growth. 
 
41. 
Eleven  major  ODA  partners  have  planned  to  provide  financial  assistance  under  the 
PRSC 6 framework (Appendix 5). All financing partners participated in PRSC 6 preparation and 
are  actively  involved  in  those  policy  areas  where  they  have  strengths.  Given  the  many  active 
development partners in Viet Nam, several financing partners are involved in the same reform 
sectors.  However,  certain  financing  partners  may  have  greater  comparative  advantage  in  a 
subsector than others. For example, within the financial sector, the World Bank and Japan Bank 
for  International  Cooperation  (JBIC)  specialize  in  banking  reforms,  while  ADB  specializes  in 
nonbanking reforms. ADB has participated in policy dialogue related to many reform sectors in 
comparison  with  other  development  partners.  PRSC  6,  which  has  a  national  economy-wide 
reform  agenda,  complements  these  ADB-assisted  activities  (Appendix  2,  Figure  A2.1).  In 
addition,  ADB  staff  have  actively  participated  in  PRSC  policy  dialogue  with  other  financing 
partners, thus ensuring synergy between the PRSC multisector policy actions and ADB sector-
based programs and projects. This allows ADB to verify that PRSC 6 conditions do not conflict 
with  policy  conditions  under  ADB’s  ongoing  sector  loans.  In  fact,  ADB’s  participation  in  this 
dialogue enables it to influence the reform agenda in a way  that complements ADB’s ongoing 
sector loans, because the PRSC provides a clear picture of ADB’s intervention as part of and in 
relation to the aggregated efforts of all of Viet Nam’s development partners.  
 
42. 
The proposed program is expected to lead to substantial improvements in development 
outcomes. The current PRSC cycle covers the same 5-year implementation period as that of the 
SEDP. The targeted development outcomes under this PRSC cycle have been clearly identified 
(Appendix  6),  as  the  PRSC  process  has  been  supported  by  a  series  of  comprehensive 
analytical reports underlining the formulation and implementation of previous PRSCs under the 
past  5-year  cycle.  The  analytical  reports  have  helped  both  the  Government  and  development 
partners strategically identify and adjust policy actions adopted under the program. These major 
analytical  reports  include  the  annual  VDRs,  which  provide  crucial  information  and  analysis 
regarding focal issues relevant to the Government’s reform agenda.  
 
43. 
To  reduce  the  transaction  costs  of  this  rather  complex  operation  for  both  the 
Government and the participating development partners, the proposed loan pursues a program-
based approach. This approach is in line with ADB’s recent move and practices toward adopting 
program-based and sector approaches in its lending operations to reduce transaction costs for 
its  developing  member  countries  as  well  as  for  its  own  operations.  The  approach  is  not  only 
consistent  with  ADB’s  reform  agenda,15 Long-Term  Strategic  Framework,16 and  Medium-Term 
Strategy  II, 17 but  also  will  directly  help  fulfill  ADB’s  obligations  to  the  Rome  Declaration  on

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

The program loan aims to provide support to Viet Nam’s policy and institutional reforms 
46. 
that  seek  to  maintain  high  growth  and  reduce  poverty.  The  outcomes  envisaged  include 
numerous  development  targets  that  reduce  structural  weaknesses,  promote  socially  inclusive 
development,  protect  natural  resources,  and  modernize  governance  and  public  administration 
(Appendix  1)  by  supporting  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  program  under  the  policy 
framework of PRSC 6. To reduce poverty and sustain rapid economic growth, the program loan 
will  strengthen  Viet  Nam’s  reform  program  through  40  policy  actions,  12  of  which  are  tranche 
release  conditions  for  the  loan.  The  policy  matrix  is  presented  in  Appendix  4  and  the 
development  policy  letter  in  Appendix  7.  Supplementary  Appendix  B  provides  additional 
information on supporting documents demonstrating that all of the policy actions have already 
been complied with. The program’s Summary Poverty Impact Assessment elaborates the effect 
of this program loan to the poor, and is presented in Appendix 8. The policy matrix comprises 
policy measures that can be categorized into four reform pillars: 
 

(i) 

(ii) 

Pillar  I:  business  development.  Promote  global  integration  to  improve  the 
economy’s  efficiency  and  resource  allocation,  enhance  transparency  and 
accountability  in  state  and  financial  sectors,  and  strengthen  the  regulatory 
framework  for  private  sector  and  infrastructure  development  to  create  an 
enabling business environment and improved livelihoods for the poor.  
Pillar  II:  social  inclusion.  Advance  human  development  by  upgrading  the 
quality  of  education,  promoting  inclusive  education  for  disadvantaged  children,

(iii)

improving access by the poor to health services, helping secure social protection 
for the population, and promoting gender equality.   
Pillar  III:  natural  resources.  Encourage  important  policy  measures  leading  to 
more  sustainable  management  of  natural  resources,  including  the  protection  of 
land, forests, water and the environment.  
Pillar IV: modern governance. Increase transparency and accountability of the  
planning  process,  public  financial  management,  and  public  administration, 
improve  legal  transparency  and  accessibility  as  part  of  a  broader  effort  to  build
