The possible approaches to mitigate potential risks in attaining the program’s outcomes include 
(i)  upgrading  of  policies  related  to  the  banking  sector,  the  securities  market  and  the 
management of public debt; (ii) improving data availability and analytical work on issues arising 
from  rural-urban  disparities;  and  (iii)  making  rapid  improvements  in  transparency  at  various 
levels. The potential risks and their mitigating measures will be discussed in detail in Section V 
(Program Benefits, Impacts, Assumptions, and Risks).  
 
B. 

Policy Framework and Actions 

47. 
The program loan’s outputs include (i) policy advisory services by all PRSC participants 
to  assist  the  Government  in  formulating  and  implementing  the  reform  policies;  (ii)  laws, 
regulations,  and  policies  that  are  conducive  to  reforms  under  the  program  framework;  (iii) 
amendment or strengthening of laws, regulations, and policies; (iv) action plans and strategies 
that  are  strategically  important  for  attaining  targeted  development  outcomes;  and  (v)  self-
assessments and sector studies that are of strategic importance. These were achieved through 
40 policy actions in the program’s policy matrix. The following paragraphs will elaborate in detail 
certain  outputs  achieved  under  the  reform  program  through  the  strategic  and  critical  policy 
actions under the program framework.  
 
1. 
 
 
 
48. 
Global  Integration.  The  most  important  PRSC  6  policy  actions  in  relation  to  global 
integration  were  the  granting  of  trading  and  distribution  rights  to  all  foreign  firms,  in  line  with 
international  commitments,  and  the  issuance  of  regulations  and  adequate  enforcement 
mechanisms  to  guide  the  intellectual  property  law.  The  trend  in  the  area  of  global  integration 
has shifted from reducing barriers to trade in goods towards increased competition in services 
and considerable legal reform. This trend was boosted (on a multilateral as opposed to bilateral 
basis) through Viet Nam’s WTO accession in January 2007.  

Pillar I: Business Development  

49. 
SOE Reform. Significant progress in SOE reform occurred between mid-2006 and mid-
2007,  in  the  form  of  additional  divestiture  and  better  performance  monitoring.  The  number  of 
sectors in which 100%  state  ownership  is  to be retained  was further  reduced (from 29  to 19), 
and  the  remaining  activities  are  primarily  strategic  in  nature.  This  should  lead  to  more  SOEs 
being  divested,  with  share  auctions  now  utilized  as  the  main  mechanism  for  equitization,  and 
the participation of foreign strategic investors allowed. Although the state still retains a share of 
the  capital  in  many  sectors  and  enterprises,  additional  steps  have  been  taken  to  ensure  that 
these  are  managed  efficiently.  All  SOEs  are  now  classified  according  to  their  performance— 
based on their  turnover, profitability, servicing of debts and  compliance with  the law—with  the 
classification  results  published.  In  addition,  the  exercise  of  ownership  rights  on  behalf  of  the 
state  is  being  transferred  from  line  ministries  and  provincial  governments  to  the  State  Capital 
Investment Corporation (SCIC), a for-profit organization under the Prime Minister. This transfer 

  

15 

of ownership should resolve the conflict of interest that ministries and provinces formerly faced 
when  formulating  and  implementing  policies  that  affected  the  enterprises  they  ran.  This  also 
enables  a  shift  away  from  administrative  management  towards  commercially  oriented 
management  of  SOEs.  Corporate  governance  at  the  equitized  SOEs  is  also  expected  to  be 
improved.  The  former  holdings  of  line  ministries  and  agencies  in  nearly  200  equitized  SOEs 
were  transferred  to  SCIC.  This  has  resulted  in  improved  corporate  governance,  as  SCIC 
operation is more commercially oriented. By 2006, the number of equitized SOEs totaled 3,060. 
There were over 2,100 remaining SOEs, including 335 public utility companies and 295 public 
farms. The Government plans to equitize 1,500 additional SOEs by end-2010. The Government 
also  accelerated  the  equitization  of  over  71  general  corporations,  with  20  scheduled  to  be 
equitized  in  2007.  A  number  of  large  general  corporations—including  four  state-owned 
commercial banks, telecommunication companies such as Viet Nam Mobile Telecom Services 
Company (MobiFone), VinaPhone Telecoms Operator Service Company (VinaFone), and Hanoi 
and  Saigon  Brewery  Companies—are  preparing  their  initial  public  offerings  (IPOs).  Overall, 
equitization  helps improve  the performance of enterprises.  A survey of 550 equitized SOEs  in 
2005 showed that 90 percent of the companies reported improved financial performance, with 
increases  in  sales  of  13%  and  profit  increases  of  nearly  10%.  Salaries  of  employees  in  those 
companies also increased.18  
 
50. 
The Government has requested ADB to provide assistance in (i) accelerating the pace of 
SOE  reform,  including  equitization  and  listing  on  the  stock  exchange;  and  (ii)  promoting 
development  of  a  market-based  and  internationally  competitive  corporate  sector  by  providing 
long-term finance. A preparatory TA project and two subsequent program loans on SOE reform 
(SOE  Reform  and  Corporate  Governance  Facilities  I  and  II)  are  included  in  Viet  Nam  CSP 
2007–2010.  

Financial  Sector  Reform. An important policy action under the previous program loan 
51. 
was adoption of the ambitious banking reform strategy, which established a deadline of 2010 for 
equitization  of  state-owned  commercial  banks.  This  program  loan  now  focuses  on  the 
implementation of a strategy aiming to strengthen the commercial orientation of SOCBs, which 
still dominate the market, based on the assumption that regulation and technical upgrades alone 
would  not  be  sufficient  to  overcome  the  interference  of  non-commercial  objectives  in  lending 
decisions,  especially  at  the  provincial  level.  Introducing  private  capital  in  SOCBs,  with  the 
participation of strategic foreign investors with recognized resources and expertise, was seen as 
necessary to accomplish this transformation. The program loan’s policy actions under PRSC 6 
prepared  the  ground  for  the  equitization  of  two  SOCBs,  including  one  of  the  largest,  over  the 
next  year.  The  equity  stake  allowed  to  foreign  strategic  investors  was  increased,  while  all 
SOCBs were required to disclose their financial statements in line with internationally accepted 
standards.  

52. 
Private  Sector  Development.  Policies  to  support  the  development  of  the  already 
vibrant  private  sector  remain  centered  around  the  removal  of  administrative  barriers  to  entry. 
Through  this  program  loan,  processing  time  was  reduced  and  the  fee  structure  for  business 
registration  was  rationalized.  The  authority  to  issue  investment  certificates  was  clarified,  more 
details  were  provided  on  sectors  where  investment  is  conditional,  and  the  documentation  for 
investment registration or evaluation was standardized. A consultative mechanism to streamline 
licenses  and  oversee  the  implementation  of  a  new  investment-enterprise  regime  was 
established, and guidelines and options were issued for foreign investors to transition to such   a 

                                                 
18 National Assembly. 2006. SOE Reform Report to the National Assembly 2006. Hanoi. 
 

 

 

 16 

regime. The single-window mechanism for businesses was adopted in selected provinces and 
covers registration, tax, and seal formalities. A monitoring mechanism to assess the constraints 
faced  by  businesses  was  set  up  in  parallel,  under  the  form  of  an  investment  climate  module 
attached to the enterprise survey, which is conducted every two years. The sample used for this 
module is representative at the provincial level, facilitating comparisons of business friendliness 
across local authorities. 

53. 
Infrastructure.  Mechanisms  are  being  set  up  to  increase  the  efficiency  of  public 
resources and the volume of private funding. In relation to public resources, the decentralization 
of investment ownership should lead to a better integration of capital and recurrent budgets in 
the road transport sector. About 40 projects will be transferred to the Viet Nam Roads Authority, 
which previously was responsible only for the maintenance budget. The transfer of investment 
ownership is expected to strengthen the Ministry of Transport’s oversight function by separating 
its former dual role as project owner and supervisor. The adoption of wastewater charges based 
on  cost  recovery  should  also  contribute  to  the  sustainability  of  investments  in  water  and 
sanitation.  This  measure  is  accompanied  by  appropriate  caps  to  protect  the  poor.  The 
mobilization  of  private  funding  for  infrastructure  projects  should  be  facilitated  by  the  newly 
issued  build-operate-transfer  decree,  which  clarifies  contract  specifications, 
investor 
qualifications and treatment of unsolicited proposals. 

Pillar II: Social Inclusion  

 
2. 
 
Education.  The  government  strategy  expanded  coverage  of  high-quality  schooling  at 
54. 
lower levels with competition and incentives for excellence at higher levels. While the coverage 
of primary education has continued to expand, quality remains an issue, with children in poorer 
areas being at a disadvantage. Fundamental quality standard levels for schools were introduced 
under  the  previous  PRSC  cycle,  and  a  key  policy  action  under  this  program  loan  extends 
performance standards for primary teachers nationwide. The implementation of such standards 
will rely on evidence-based assessments of teacher performance, as opposed to diplomas and 
seniority. In addition, transparent criteria for university admission quotas have been adopted on 
a pilot basis. 

55. 
Health.  A  fundamental  transformation  in  the  government’s  approach  to  HIV/AIDS  has 
taken  place  in  recent  years  and  is  now  being  consolidated.  Risky  behaviors—including  the 
practice  of  commercial  sex  and  the  use  of  intravenous  drugs—were  traditionally  labeled  as 
“social  evils”,  often  resulting  in  stigma  and  discrimination  for  the  affected  populations.  That 
approach  changed  considerably  under  the  previous  cycle,  with  a  new  strategy  emphasizing 
prevention  and  treatment  over  repression.  This  public  health  approach  is  reflected  in  the 
HIV/AIDS law passed in June 2006 and the subsequent preparation of a comprehensive set of 
action  plans  to  expand  harm  reduction.  These  action  plans  foresee  the  introduction  of  needle 
exchange and methadone substitution programs.  Meanwhile, an effort  was undertaken across 
the  health  sector  as  a  whole  to  improve  the  budgetary  balance  between  health  infrastructure, 
human resources, subsidies and preventive care.  

56. 
Social Protection. The pension program design was improved, extending coverage and 
make  its  compulsory  component  financially  viable.  Until  the  mid-1990s,  only  public  sector 
workers  were  entitled  to  old-age,  disability  and  survivor  benefits,  under  a  non-contributory 
program  funded  out  of  general  government  resources.  This  program  was  subsequently 
extended  on  a  contributory  basis  to  all  formal  sector  workers,  but  old-age  pension  benefits 
remained determined by average salaries in the years preceding retirement. The period covered 
by this credit saw the passing of the first-ever Social Insurance Law, which determines pension 

  

17 

benefits  for  private  sector  workers  on  the  basis  of  their  average  salary  over  all  the  years  in 
which they contributed. In a rapidly growing economy, this average salary is substantially lower 
than the salary in the years preceding retirement, so the law dramatically improved the financial 
viability of the system. It also introduced a voluntary pension program for farmers and informal 
sector  workers,  making  it  possible  to  gradually  extend  the  coverage  of  the  social  insurance 
system.  This  voluntary  program  is  currently  in  its  design  phase.  However,  current  pension 
formulas retain shortcomings despite the system’s stronger financial viability and its potentially 
broader  coverage.  Under  the  new  law,  there  are  considerable  gaps  between  the  level  of 
benefits for men and women, and for public and private sector workers. In addition, benefits are 
far  removed  from  the  actuarial  benchmark,  which  encourages  relatively  short  contribution 
periods and underreporting of earnings.   

57. 
Gender.  While  gender  equality  indicators  are  better  in  Viet  Nam  than  in  many  other 
developing countries, steps are being taken to narrow the remaining gaps. The passing of a law 
on  gender equality, a policy action  taken under  this program loan, is an important  step in  this 
direction. It is recognized that regulation alone is not sufficient, as abuses are often unreported 
and enforcement capacities limited, but the new law does serve to unify the legal framework to 
address gender disparities and increases women’s participation in decision making. 

3. 

Pillar III: Natural Resources  
 

58. 
Land  and  Forest.  Two  main  issues  stand  out  in  relation  to  land.  First,  forest 
management remains largely under the control of state forestry enterprises (SFEs), which has 
resulted in a mixing of commercial and protective functions. There is a risk, however, that SFE 
restructuring could lead to encroachment upon forest land by outsiders, to the detriment of local 
populations, especially ethnic minorities, whose livelihoods depend to a large extent on the use 
of  forests  as  a  public  good.  To  address  this  risk,  the  government  issued  the  National  Forest 
Development  Strategy,  which  is  designed  to  strengthen  linkages  between  the  protective  and 
economic functions of forests, and to promote ownership by local households and communities. 
The strategy addresses revisions to the 5 million hectare Forest Plan, and aims to improve the 
balance  between  forest  protection  and  multi-purpose  forestation,  and  promotes  policies  that 
encourage farmers to live with the forests.  

59. 
The  second  critical  issue  faced  by  Viet  Nam  in  relation  to  land  management  concerns 
land conversion, reclamation and resettlement in the context of rapid urbanization. Close to one 
million people may be moving every year to urban and peri-urban areas, and there is extensive 
clearing of land for infrastructure development or to host industrial parks. Lack of transparency 
in reclamation and conversion plans may result in sizeable capital gains for those with access to 
the  relevant  information,  while  insufficient  compensation  for  affected  populations  is  leading  to 
recurrent  social  unrest.  The  Land  Law,  approved  under  the  previous  PRSC  series,  paved  the 
way for the use of market prices as the basis for compensation. But gaps remained in relation to 
land occupants lacking appropriate tenure documentation, which is common, as the transfer of 
land  to  households  and  firms  is  still  ongoing  in  Viet  Nam.  Under  PRSC  6,  resettlement  and 
compensation procedures have been clarified for those cases where occupants lack a land use 
right certificate (LUC), and mechanisms have been set up to handle complaints. 

60. 
Environment.  Development  sustainability  also  depends  on  the  appropriate  control  of 
pollution  and  environmental  damage  resulting  from  both  public  and  private  sector  business 
activities.  Considerable  progress  was  made  during  the  previous  cycle  on  the  use  of 
environmental  impact  assessments  for  large  investment  projects.  This  program  loan  now 
requires  both  mandatory  consultation  with  communities  where  projects  are  to  be  located  and 
incorporation of local feedback when reporting back to the relevant authorities. 

 

 

 18 

4. 

Pillar IV: Modern Governance 

 
61. 
Planning Process. The transformation of planning processes—from the direct allocation 
of resources to the strategic steering of the economy—has continued during the current 5-year 
period of the SEDP 2006-2010. In the command and control economy, the MPI would play the 
role  of  an  arbiter  in  the  selection  of  investment  projects  submitted  by  various  government 
bodies.  With  investment  decisions  devolved  to  the  National  Assembly  and  People’s  Councils, 
the  role  of  MPI  has  shifted  towards  the  allocation  of  the  budget  envelope  available  for  capital 
expenditures.  Norms  were  adopted  to  allocate  state  capital  expenditures  transparently  across 
provinces,  using  criteria  such  as  population,  poverty  and  ethnicity,  and  served  to  make 
considerably  more  resources  available  to  poorer  provinces.  In  addition,  regulations  were 
adopted for the preparation of regional development plans, specifying responsibilities, requiring 
disclosure,  and  requiring  that  infrastructure  master  plans  be  based  on  broader  regional 
development  plans.  As  a  result,  issues  such  as  comparative  advantage,  land  use  and 
population flows are expected to gain importance in determining infrastructure network layouts. 

62. 
Public  Financial  Management.  Public  financial  management  reform  has  focused  on 
strengthening  systems  and  increasing  transparency.  The  State  Audit  of  Viet  Nam  (SAV)  was 
established  as  a  specialized  agency  under  the  National  Assembly  towards  the  end  of  the 
previous  cycle,  resulting  in  the  first-ever  disclosure  of  the  SAV  audit  results  and  annual  audit 
plan.  In  addition,  a  report  on  budget  execution  for  the  current  year  and  the  budget  plan  for 
forthcoming  year  were  both  published;  these  will  be  published  annually  in  the  future. 
Regulations  were  also  issued  requiring  periodic  disclosure  of  the  amount  and  composition  of 
external  public  debt,  signaling  an  increased  emphasis  on  the  management  of  resources  and 
liabilities, as compared to the previous focus on public expenditures. In addition, a regulation to 
guide the establishment and issuance of benchmark government bonds was implemented, and 
the  administrative  procedures  for  all  taxes  were  consolidated  into  a  single  law,  modernizing 
assessment and enforcement methods. 

63. 
Legal  Development.  Increased  oversight  of  government  actions  at  both  national  and 
local levels has been a common theme underlying the legal reforms adopted under this program 
loan. The National Assembly has become increasingly active in its supervisory role, especially 
since  the  passing  of  the  Budget  Law  of  2002.  This  trend  was  reinforced  recently  with  the 
establishment of separate legal, judicial, economic, and budget committees, which are expected 
to include a greater proportion of permanent members than in the past. A key new task of the 
judiciary  committee  will  be  overseeing  the  Government’s  anticorruption  activities.  A  separate 
legislative committee will be in a better position to ensure consistency between different laws, 
improve the quality of their drafting, and coordinate the assessments and recommendations of 
the various National Assembly committees on proposed legislation. A similar trend is noticeable 
at  local  levels.  A  new  ordinance  on  grassroots  democracy  strengthens  information  disclosure, 
public  participation,  and  accountability  of  officials  in  the  preparation  and  implementation  of 
commune-level  policies.  Recent  legal  developments  have  also  aimed  at  promoting  access  to 
justice and  recognizing civil society organizations. Under this operation, legal aid mechanisms 
for  marginalized  and  vulnerable  groups  were  simplified  and  broadened,  and  policies  adopted 
encouraging the participation of non-state establishments in the delivery of public services. 

64. 
Fighting  Corruption.  The  Government  is  now  moving  to  implement  its  anticorruption 
program. Key laws and regulations have been passed, including the pivotal Anticorruption Law. 
The  current  challenge—of  translating  resolve  into  action—has  been  addressed  in  part  by 
several measures adopted during the period covered by this credit. These include establishment 
of a steering committee against corruption, headed by the Prime Minister, which has the power 

  

19 

to  suspend  high-level  officials  if  they  are  suspected  of  wrongdoing.  It  is  already  engaged  in 
investigating  some  high-profile  cases,  and  the  findings  are  to  be  made  public.  In  addition,  the 
office  of  the  national  steering  committee  was  set  up  under  the  Anticorruption  Law  as  an 
independent  entity,  which  does  not  belong  to  the  existing  government  agency  system.  The 
results  of  corruption  investigations  in  cases  overseen  by  the  Government  Inspectorate  were 
disclosed, and a legal  framework  established  to protect and reward corruption-related whistle-
blowing.  

C. 

Important Features 

An  environmental  assessment  has  been  prepared  for  the  policy  matrix  of  the  program 
65. 
loan  in  keeping  with  the  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002)  and  the  environmental  safeguard 
requirements of ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines.19  
 
On  balance,  the  reforms  proposed  as  part  of  this  program  loan  are  expected  to  have 
66. 
wide-reaching  positive  impacts  on  socioeconomic  conditions  throughout  Viet  Nam  and  will 
assist the Government fulfill its development objectives as outlined in the SEDP. The majority of 
the proposed reforms are likely to have either a positive impact or no impact. Where possible, 
enhancement  measures  have  been  developed  for  integration  into  the  reform  process  to 
optimize the predicted positive impacts. Two series of reforms—those relating to (i) an increase 
in granting of trading and distribution rights to foreign firms, and (ii) to increased private sector 
development—have been identified as having an unknown impact, because of their potential to 
result in both positive and negative effects. Mitigation measures have been developed to offset 
any  potential  adverse  impacts  and  maximize  their  positive  impacts.  No  reforms  have  been 
identified as having a negative impact. 
 
67.  Monitoring relating to environmental issues will be integrated into the overall monitoring 
program developed for PRSC operations; a series of suggested environment-related monitoring 
indicators has been developed for this purpose.  
 
The program loan will not have any impact on involuntary resettlement or on indigenous 
68. 
people,  as  it  has  no  investment  component.  None  of  the  policy  actions  associated  with  this 
program will trigger any activities related to indigenous people during the implementation period. 
The  current  PRSC  cycle  recognizes  the  potential  risk  of  income  disparity  between  urban  and 
rural  as  well  as  the  Kinh  majority  and  ethnic  minorities,  as  did  PRSC  5.  The  Government  is 
aware  of  this  potential  risk  and  commits  to  formulating  and  implementing  preventative  and 
mitigating measures. This potential risk is not viewed as being likely to damage Viet Nam’s track 
record  on  these  issues  during  the  short  program  implementation  period.  A  social  and  poverty 
impact  assessment  was  undertaken  in  relation  to  the  program  loan  (see  Appendix  8).  The 
assessment  concludes  that  the  activities  will  have  no  adverse  impacts  on  indigenous  people, 
and no gender implications.  
 
D. 

Financing Plan 

69. 
A  total  of  about  $354  million  for  PRSC  6  operations  is  expected  to  be  funded  through 
ODA  resources.  The  World  Bank  has  already  approved  a  $175  million  credit  from  the 
International  Development  Association  to  support  PRSC  6.  Financing  partners  providing 
concessional  loans  include  ADB  ($15  million),  JBIC  (¥3.5  billion),  and  Germany  (€6  million). 
Financing partners providing grants include Agencia Española de Cooperación Internacional (€5

70. 
The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $15  million  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources as ADB’s support to SEDP implementation following the policy framework of PRSC 6. 
The  program  loan  would  contribute  to  financing  the  costs  of  adjustment  resulting  from 
implementation of the policy matrix, particularly the prior actions for PRSC 6, and to supporting 
and  facilitating  the  Government’s  continued  and  deepened  reform  program  for  poverty

The loan will have a 24-year term including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 
71. 
1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms 
and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The loan proceeds may be used to finance 
eligible imports incurred within 180 days prior to the date of loan effectiveness. The loan closing 
date will be 31 December 2008. 
 
72. 
Some of the reforms supported by PRSC 6 entail substantial cost to the Government to 
finance.  Policy  measures  supported  by  the  PRSC  operations,  such  as  the  safety  net  for 
redundant SOE workers, recapitalization of SOCBs, provincial healthcare for the poor, and the 
increased education budget allocation require additional spending. These are costly and specific 
to the PRSCs. The cost of adjustment of the PRSCs is therefore greater than the cost of these 
clearly PRSC-specific items, which is estimated to range from more than $300 million to more 
than  $700  million  per  year  from  2002  to  2006.  The  estimated  cost  of  some  specific  PRSC-
related measures for the PRSC 6 implementation period is approximately $1,420 million, i.e., (i) 
health  care  funds  for  the  poor,  about  $90  million;  (ii)  increased  spending  on  education 
proportional to the Government budget, about $540 million; (iii) social safety net program for the 
retrenched SOE workers, about $100 million; and (iv) SOCB recapitalization, about $690 million.  
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Program Management 

73. 
SBV, as the Executing Agency, will be responsible for overall program implementation, 
including  administration  and  disbursement  of  loan  proceeds,  maintenance  of  accounts,  and 
preparation of semiannual progress reports on program implementation. The program is being 
implemented  through  all  line  ministries  and  government  agencies  in  accordance  with  the  loan 
agreement.  While  the  ODA  funds  raised  through  the  PRSC  process  provide  resources  to  the 
state budget to implement the reforms, the PRSC operations have also served as an effective 
coordination device between the Government and the many development partners. On behalf of 
the  Government,  SBV  coordinated  the  overall  processing  of  PRSC  6.  The  World  Bank 
coordinated  the  process  for  the  development  partners.  The  number  of  financing  partners  has 
steadily increased, from 4 in PRSC 1 (approved in 2002) to 11 for PRSC 6. The development 
partners  have  participated  in  the  PRSC  process  by  forming  working  groups  with  the 
Government  that  cover  all  economic  policy  areas.  Staff  of  ADB’s  Viet  Nam  Resident  Mission 
have  actively  participated  in  several  other  working  groups  including  the  small-  and  medium-
sized  enterprise  (SME)  development  partnership,  financial  sector  partnership,  and  public 
administrative reform partnership. Given the comprehensive nature of the PRSC reform process 

  

21 

and the ever-growing number of financing partners, in January 2005 SBV established a program 
coordination  unit,  comprised  of  competent  staff.  The  unit  deals  with  the  program  agenda, 
including  monitoring  and  reporting,  awareness  raising,  capacity  building,  and  reform  outcome 
dissemination.  It  has  frequently  interacted  with  the  World  Bank  and  the  financing  partners  of 
PRSC 6, including ADB. 
 
The Steering Committee was established in June 2007  to  advise the  Prime  Minister  in 
74. 
developing and implementing the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy and 
Poverty Reduction Support Credits in consistence with the purposes of the SEDP 2006–2010. 
Such steering committee is chaired by the deputy prime minister in charge of economic reforms, 
and consists of representatives from relevant line ministries and government agencies. An SBV 
deputy  governor  and  a  vice  minister  of  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Investment  act  as  the 
standing vice chairpersons. To represent PRSC policy reform areas, the steering committee has 
several representatives from key economic ministries (e.g., the ministries of agriculture and rural 
development;  education  and  training;  finance;  foreign  affairs;  justice;  industry  and  trade;  and 
labor, invalids, and social affairs; and), as well as the Office of the Government.  
 

2. 

Implementation Period 

The program period is from 30 June 2007 to 31 December 2008. 

75. 
 

3. 

Disbursement and Procurement  

76. 
The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche, contingent upon loan effectiveness. The 
loan  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  for  a  broad  range  of  imports,  subject  to  a  negative  list  of 
ineligible  items  (Appendix  9).  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign 
exchange  costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB 
member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral sources. In accordance with the provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement 
Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans,20 the proceeds of the program loan 
will  be  disbursed  to  Viet  Nam  as  the  Borrower.  No  supporting  import  documentation  will  be 
required,  provided  the  value  of  Viet  Nam’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember 
countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under other official development assistance is 
equal to or greater than the amount of the loan expected to be disbursed. The Government will 
certify  its  compliance  with  this  formula  with  its  withdrawal  request.  Otherwise,  import 
documentation under existing procedures will be required. ADB will have the right to audit  the 
use  of  loan  proceeds  and  to  verify  the  accuracy  of  the  Borrower's  certification.  As  such,  the 
procedures for procurement and disbursement of funds, and the use of counterpart funds, are 
felt to be satisfactory.

Strengthening  the  management  of  public  expenditures  has  been  a  priority  of  the

Government over the last decade and significant progress has been made in this respect. A first

Major developments in public financial management include empowering the National Assembly 
with  increased  government  accountability  for  the  use  of  public  resources;  increasing 
transparency  for  all  agencies  using  budget  resources,  including  SOEs,  public  investment 
projects and statutory funds; establishing the SAV as a technically independent unit under the 
National  Assembly;  and  gradual  integration  of  capital  and  recurrent  expenditures  through 
forward-looking  budgets  and  resource  allocation  norms.  Twenty-six  national  private  sector 
accounting  and  37  auditing  standards  consistent  with  international  practice  have  been  issued. 
The government is currently making a major investment in a new and integrated Treasury and 
Budget Management Information System (TABMIS). Progress is being made in developing new 
business processes for TABMIS, including (i) a unified Chart of Accounts, (ii) further integration 
of  recurrent  and  capital  budget  execution  processes,  (iii)  clarification  of  issues  related  to 
reporting  ODA  on  budget,  and  (iv)  development  of  standard  reports  to  strengthen  budget 
execution. 
 
79. 
The World Bank and MOF commenced preparation of the CFAA Update in April 2007 in 
consultation  with  and  with  the  participation  of  many  other  development  partners,  including 
ADB,23 AusAID,  Canada,  Denmark,  DFID,  EC,  France,  Germany,  Ireland,  and  Sweden.  The 
final  report  will  be  available  in  late  2007.  The  update  will  provide  an  assessment  of  public 
financial  management  by  examining  budget  development,  budget  execution  and  accounting, 
internal and external reporting, internal controls, internal and external auditing, monitoring and 
legislative  oversight  and  scrutiny,  financial  management  capacity  and  financial  accountability 
risks.  
 
80. 
The  fiduciary  risks  of  the  current  public  financial  management  systems,  (budgeting, 
accounting, reporting and auditing) are assessed as moderate. Since the IMF does not currently 
have  a  program  in  Viet  Nam,  it  is  not  possible  to  rely  on  its  assessment  of  the  control 
environment of the SBV. However, the enactment of the Audit Law of 2005 helps address the 
issues related to audit and accounting arrangements. The Audit Law has established the SAV 
as an independent institution reporting to the National Assembly, with the auditor general being 
appointed and dismissed by the National Assembly. Audit reports were made public for the first 
time in 2006. The SBV will be subject to auditing by SAV on an annual basis.

Program Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 

82. 
Progress in the implementation of the program loan’s reform agenda will be monitored in 
parallel with the SEDP M&E framework through a well–defined, streamlined set of development 
indicators.  The  SEDP  M&E  framework  was  developed  by  MPI,  with  support  from  ADB,  World 
Bank  and  UNDP,  and  in  close  consultation  with  line  ministries.  Some  indicators  in  the 
framework  are common with the National Statistics Indicator System (NSIS) developed by  the 
General  Statistics  Office  (GSO);  others,  although  not  included  in  the  NSIS,  can  be  calculated 
from  Viet  Nam  Household  Living  Standards  Survey  data.  Data  for  a  few  others,  e.g.  for 
assessing satisfaction with government services, will have to be collected.  
 
PRSC  6  will  continue  to  build  on  its  successes  in  the  previous  5-year  PRSC  cycle  in 
83. 
streamlining  numerous  ongoing  M&E  initiatives.  Key  sources  of  monitoring  information  for 
poverty  and  program  outcomes  include  the  proposed  biannual  household  living  standard 
survey,  periodic  participatory  poverty  assessments,  small  business  registration  survey,  public 
expenditure  tracking  survey,  as  well  as  quarterly  progress  reports  from  the  relevant  sector 
ministries and committees implementing the reform program. In some areas the set of indicators 
proposed  in  the  VDR  goes  beyond  the  SEDP  M&E  framework;  this  is  the  case  in  relation  to 
governance, where monitoring experience is limited and there is less experience in the use of 
enterprise  and  household  surveys,  as  opposed  to  administrative  self-reporting.  However, 
because  reliable  data  need  to  be  collected  from  surveys  and  other  sources  with  demanding 
implementation  requirements,  the  monitoring  of  progress  towards  development  outcomes 
cannot  be  conducted  on  an  annual  basis.  It  is  expected  that  the  new  PRSC  cycle  will  involve 
some annual monitoring but only two in-depth assessments, towards the middle and at the end 
of the cycle. 
 

V. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

84. 
First,  through  policy  actions  designed  to  facilitate  business  development,  the  loan  will 
increase efficiency, accelerate economic growth, and create jobs. These policy actions will help 
improve  the  regulatory  framework  for  private  sector  development,  and  enhance  transparency 
and accountability in SOE operations and in banking. Second, policy actions addressing social 
inclusion  will  result  in  benefits  that  include  improved  quality  of  education,  improved  access  of 
the  poor  to  health  services,  a  reformed  social  protection  system,  and  promotion  of  gender 
equality.  Third,  through  policy  actions  addressing  natural  resources,  the  loan  will  help  secure 
land ownership and address the resettlement and compensation process, as well as promoting 
more sustainable management of natural resources. Fourth, through policy actions addressing 
modern  governance,  benefits  include  increased  transparency  and  accountability  of  public 
finances,  and  improved  legal  transparency  and  accessibility.  These  will  be  achieved  through 
better coordination of plans and budgets, adoption of the medium-term expenditure framework, 
and greater accountability in public finance and public administration. 
   
85. 
Three  potential  risks  are  associated  with  emerging  imbalances  accompanying  Viet 
Nam’s  entry  into  a  new  phase  of  development,  with  greater  global  integration  and  a  more 
market-oriented  economy.  The  first  potential  risk  is  the  vulnerability  that  stems  from  possible 
turbulence  in  the  financial  sector,  as  the  supervisory  and  regulatory  capacity  of  monetary 
authorities  has  not  matched  the  expansion  in  capital  markets.  The  second  risk  relates  to  the 
massive  inflows  of  FDI  and  increased  competition  in  formerly  protected  sectors.  This  change 

 

 

 24 

may  test  the  ability  of  Viet  Nam  to  preserve  social  inclusion,  and  may  cause  some  groups  to 
lose  in  the  short  term.  The  third  possible  risk  involves  potential  corruption  and  social  strife 
related to rapid urbanization and infrastructure development. 
 
86. 
Through  appropriate  measures  and  proactive  programs  undertaken  during  program 
implementation, the Government will take steps to mitigate potential risks. ADB, along with other 
PRSC financing partners, has conducted analytical studies to help policymakers formulate and 
execute  mitigating  and  corrective  measures  in  anticipation  of  these  potential  risks.  These 
corrective measures have been included in the proposed series of PRSCs, which includes this 
program loan.  The  first  risk—related  to  imbalance in  the  financial sector—could be addressed 
by  rapid  upgrading  of  policies  related  to  the  banking  sector,  the  securities  market  and  the 
management of public debt, all of which are part of the proposed reform program. The second 
risk—related  to  social  inclusion  and  environmental  sustainability—could  be  mitigated  by  the 
strong commitment of the Government to keep growth inclusive and sustainable. This risk could 
also  be  addressed  through  improvements  in  data  availability  and  analytical  work  on  issues 
arising  from  rural-urban  disparities,  which  are  included  as  part  of  the  PRSC  process.  Rapid 
feedback  channels  from  affected  stakeholders,  inclusive  policies  in  the  social  sectors,  and 
transparent  mechanisms  to  transfer  resources  to  poorer  regions  are  among  the  mitigating 
measures supported by the proposed series of operations. The third risk—related to corruption 
and  social  strife  caused  by  rapid  urbanization  and  infrastructure  development—could  be 
addressed  by  making  rapid  progress  in  transparency  at  various  levels,  including  in  regional 
planning, infrastructure master plans, land use and appropriate taxation, and monitoring of the 
assets of relevant civil servants.

Activities with Milestones 
To obtain the program outputs including policy actions, regulations, and sector studies, 
the following activities have been and will be carried out. 

• Meetings to discuss reform policies under the PRSC framework. Processing of each 
annual PRSC program; each participant attends at least 40 meetings including (i) 
internal meetings with sector specialists, (ii) meetings of development partners, and (iii) 
meetings between development partners and government agencies.  

• In addition to the direct PRSC-specific meetings, ADB staff participate in relevant 
partnership group meetings on several development issues related to the reform 
program of this proposed loan. The partnership group meetings of 20-plus groups are 
held at least quarterly. The main reports from all partnership group meetings are 
compiled and reported at the semiannual consultative group meetings. The results from 
partnership group meetings help improve coordination of all stakeholders beyond PRSC 
operations.  

• Assessments of the Vietnamese economy as well as socioeconomic and development 
strategy and policies by development partners, including the annual Viet Nam 
Development Reports (prepared jointly by several development partners including ADB) 
and the joint staff advisory note on the Poverty Reduction Strategy (prepared jointly by 
the International Monetary Fund and World Bank with inputs from all development 
partners including ADB). These assessments provide background analyses to formulate 
the policy matrix of the program.

Sri SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

The  5-Year  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  as  the  National  Poverty  Reduction 
Strategy 

A. 

 

1. 

Formulation of the Plan 

than  administrative  reporting 

 
1. 
Comprehensive  economic  reforms  undertaken  during  the  last  Poverty  Reduction 
Support  Credit  (PRSC)  cycle  have  led  to  rapid  economic  growth  and  remarkable  progress  on 
development outcomes. Viet Nam has been among the fastest-growing economies in the world 
for  almost  two  decades.  There  was  a  considerable  acceleration  of  reforms  around  2001, 
justifying  the  first  5-year  PRSC  cycle,  and  then  again  in  2006.  The  former  involved  (i)  the 
passing of an enterprise law that greatly facilitated business registration and operation, (ii) the 
signing of a bilateral trade agreement with the United States that strengthened global integration 
and  resulted  in  important  legal  improvements,  and  (iii)  the  adoption  of  the  first  serious  steps 
towards  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE)  divestiture  and  the  strengthening  of  public  financial 
management.  Emerging  from  massive  poverty  less  than  two  decades  ago,  Viet  Nam  is  now 
aiming to attain middle-income status by 2010.  
 
2. 
The  new  socioeconomic  development  plan  (SEDP)  2006–2010  articulates  the  aim  to 
attain  middle-income  status  by  2010,  reflecting  the  transition  towards  strategic  planning  for  a 
market economy. The SEDP, approved by the National Assembly in June 2006, illustrates the 
depth  of  Viet  Nam’s  transition.  Unlike  previous  5-year  plans,  which  focused  on  quantitative 
targets  as  if  the  state  was  still  in  charge  of  producing  most  goods  and  services,  the  SEDP 
emphasizes  development  outcomes  and  the  policy  reforms  needed  to  attain  them.  It  relies  on 
data  analysis  rather 
its  diagnosis  and 
recommendations.  It has also led to the adoption of a  framework  to  monitor progress towards 
attaining development outcomes.  
 
3. 
The official development assistance (ODA) community has aligned its efforts behind the 
SEDP, while acknowledging that other key documents will shape reforms in the coming years. 
Such  alignment  is  a  testament  to  the  strong  ownership  of  the  reform  program  by  the 
Government of Viet Nam (the Government). It also reflects satisfaction with the process through 
which  the  SEDP  was  prepared.  Above  all,  the  SEDP  is  seen  as  both  a  credible  and  a 
sustainable strategy to foster economic growth and poverty reduction. It is credible because of 
the ambitious policy reforms it proposes, which are organized around three pillars: (i) supporting 
business development, (ii) keeping growth inclusive, and (iii) better managing natural resources. 
A  fourth,  underlying  pillar  concerns  the  need  to  modernize  institutions  so  as  to  deliver  on  the 
other  three  fronts.  The  SEDP  is  seen  as  sustainable  because  it  should  lead  to  manageable 
levels of public debt by 2010. 
 
4. 
Unlike  the  previous  SEDP,  the  new  SEDP  is  focused  and  clearly  defines  development 
targets,  identifies  appropriate  policies  to  attain  those  targets,  and  aligns  resources  to  those 
policies.  The  country’s  development  goals,  which  are  a  local  version  of  the  Millennium 
Development Goals, are among the key targets pursued in the SEDP (Table A2.1); this parallels 
how  key  targets  were  pursued  in  the  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy 
(CPRGS) that governed the previous PRSC cycle.  
 
5. 
The SEDP provides a framework for poverty reduction policies, programs, and actions in 
Viet  Nam  (Figure  A2.1).  The  ODA  community  has  adopted  the  SEDP  as  the  reference 
document for planning and formulating external assistance.

2. 

The Poverty Reduction Support Credit Process  

 
6. 
The policy actions supported through the PRSC process can be seen as a distillation of 
the SEDP and other development strategies and plans. The PRSC policy actions are aimed at 
identifying  a  coherent  sequence  of  key  measures  in  each  area  over  the  medium  term. 
Identification  of  the  policy  actions  needed  to  attain  the  development  outcomes  documented  in 
the  SEDP  has  been  strongly  influenced  by  the  progress  reports  of  the  implementation  of  the 
previous National Poverty Reduction Strategy, namely the CPRGS, and analytical work carried 
out  by  the  development  partners.  The  annual  Viet  Nam  Development  Reports  (VDRs)—which 
are  prepared  in  partnership  by  the  World  Bank  and  other  development  partners,  including  the 
Asian Development bank (ADB)— have played a very important role in this respect. In addition 
to  the  CPRGS  and  PRSC-related  studies  and  reports,  sector  work  reports  and  assessments 
done under each development partner’s sector-based programs and projects also provide input 
to ensure the complementarity and efficiency of the PRSC reform agenda. Table A2.2 illustrates 
the timing and relation of the strategy, implementation, analyses, and sector work.  
 

3. 

Contribution: Financial and Intellectual 

 
7. 
The  ODA  community  in  Viet  Nam  considers  the  PRSC  an  important  instrument  for 
supporting  SEDP  implementation.  ADB  and  other  major  ODA  partners—including  Australia, 
Canada,  Denmark,  European  Commission,  Germany,  Ireland,  Japan,  Netherlands,  Spain,  and 
the  United  Kingdom—have  joined  with  the  World  Bank  and  contributed  both  financial  and 
intellectual resources to PRSC 6. Switzerland, while not a financing partner to PRSC 6, partially 
funds  the  PRSC  Program  Coordination  Unit,  which  is  responsible  for  coordinating  the  PRSC 
process between government agencies and development partners. The International Monetary 
Fund (IMF), France, and United Nations Development Programme, as well as the United States 
Agency  for  International development, also  participate in  policy dialogue to provide intellectual 
contributions to the PRSC process.  
 

4. 

Implementation Arrangements 

 
8. 
In  addition  to  providing  resources  to  fill  the  Government’s  financing  gap  for  the 
comprehensive  reform  agenda,  PRSC  operations  have  served  as  an  effective  coordination 
device,  supported  by  an  increasingly  large  number  of  development  partners.  The  steering 
committee  for  the  PRSCs  has  been  led  by  the  deputy  prime  minister  in  charge  of  economic 
reforms,  and  brings  together  representatives  from  all  relevant  line  ministries  and  government 
agencies.  On  the  development  partners’  side,  PRSC  operations  have  been  cofinanced  by 
several  bilateral  and  multilateral  agencies,  either  through  grants  or  parallel  lending.  More 
importantly,  the  process  saw  a  transition  in  the  role  of  financing  partners,  from  providers  of  
finance  to  partners  substantially interests and technical capacity on the ground. The number 
of development partners participating in this process has increased from 4 in PRSC 1 to 11 in 
PRSC  6.  All  development  engaged  in  the  preparation  of  operations  and  policy  dialogue  with 
government.  This  dialogue  is  organized  by  policy  areas,  in    which    development    partners 
engages electively,  based  on  their partners who seriously consider the possibility of partnering 
in  this  process  are  invited  to  participate  in  the  preparation  of  PRSC  operations,  even  if  they 
cannot  commit  to  cofinance  them  in  the  short term.   Nineteen  have  actively  contributed to

Public Financial Management  

 
preparation of PRSC 6. The PRSC group dominates the development assistance landscape in 
Viet  Nam  related  to  the  education  and  health  sectors,  environmental  sustainability,  land 
management,  legal  development,  and  public  financial  management;  these  were  all  part  of

B. 
 
9. 
The  World  Bank  and  other  PRSC  financing  parters,  except  for  the  Japan  Bank  for 
International  Cooperation  (JBIC)  and  ADB,  consider  PRSCs  to  be  budget  support  operations. 
For  ADB,  the  program  loan  that  cofinances  PRSC  6  is  considered  a  sector-wide  approach 
program,  with  loan  proceeds  supporting  the  Government’s  financing  gap,  which  is  caused  by 
the Government’s engagement in reform endeavors covered by the program. The proceeds are 
in  foreign  exchange,  with  the  loan  agreement  governing  the  use  of  the  proceeds  to  purchase 
import  goods.  The  justification  for  providing  lending  assistance  for  the  PRSC  is  based  on 
satisfactory financial management arrangements for the program, which are ultimately related to 
the  Government’s  public  financial  management.  The  following  paragraphs  offer  an  analysis  of 
Viet Nam’s fiscal stance and public financial management, which is presented in addition to the 
explanation in section IV E.4 Financial Accountability and Fiduciary Assessment (paras. 78–80 
in the main text).   
 

1. 

Overall Fiscal Trend 

 
10. 
Viet  Nam  has  been  widely  acknowledged  for  its  fiscal  prudence,  with  relatively  small 
budget deficits and a relatively small stock of both domestic and external debt. Viet Nam’s fiscal 
stance has remained extremely prudent, with the budget deficit averaging less than 2% of gross 
domestic product (GDP) over the period 1999–2003 and the stock of debt remaining under 40% 
of  GDP.  The  country  has  received  increasingly  solid  grades  from  international  organizations, 
foreign governments and sovereign risk rating agencies.  
 
The investment to GDP ratio increased from 28.3% in 1997 to 35.1% in 2003 and 41% in 
11. 
2006.  The  share  of  the  public  sector  in  GDP  has  averaged  56%,  that  of  the  domestic  private 
sector 24%, and of the foreign invested private sector 20%. High levels of investment, especially 
in  the  public  sector,  have  had  an  important  impact  on  infrastructure  development,  economic 
transformation  and  implementation  of  national  poverty  reduction  programs.  Concerns  persist 
about  the  quality  of  investments,  in  the  sense  that  more  growth  and  poverty  reduction  could 
have been attained from the same level of investment.  
 
Strong  economic  growth  was  accompanied  by  strong  growth  in  government  revenues. 
12. 
Table A2.3 below illustrates the fiscal trend. In nominal terms, government revenue and grants 
increased by an average of over 14% per  year  between 1999 and 2006. Revenue and  grants 
rose  from  around  20%  of  GDP  in  2000  to  over  28%  in  2006.  Revenues  from  consumption  of 
petroleum products and production of crude oil increased from 4.1% of GDP in 1998 to 6.5% in 
2003 and 8.6% in 2006, and account for the largest part of the revenue increase. The share of 
such revenues as a percentage of total revenue and grants rose from 20% in 1998 to 22.4% in 
2003 and 30% in 2006. As a consequence, the public budget has become more vulnerable to oil 
price shocks. Although the oil production outlook for the years ahead appears to be quite robust, 
crude oil exports cannot be relied upon as a source of revenues in the very long term.

13. 
To  strengthen  revenues  as  well  as  to  encourage  domestic  and  foreign  investment,  the 
Government  has  lightened  the  tax  burden  through  reduction  of  tax  rates  in  many  areas.  The 
enterprise  income  tax  rate  has  been  reduced  from  32%  to  28%,  and  the  number  of  VAT  tax 
rates has been cut from 4 to 3, with the highest rate (of 20%) abolished. The National Assembly 
has decided to eliminate overseas profit remittance tax and surtax on enterprise income. Most 
notably,  in  2002,  the  agricultural  land  use  tax  was  reduced  by  50%;  nearly  all  farmers  have 
been  exempted  from  such  taxes  since  2003,  meaning  that  approximately  75%  of  Viet  Nam’s 
population now pays no direct taxes.  
 
The  Government  developed  a  strategy  for  reform  of  the  tax  system  to  the  year  2010. 
14. 
The  strategy  includes  revision  of  current  tax  policies  and  reform  of  the  tax  administration 
system.  Indirect  tax  revenues  currently  account  for  a  substantial  share  (41%)  of  overall  tax 
collections, and this is expected to increase to 56% in 2010. Direct tax revenues, which account  
for 21% of  total revenues, would increase to 24% given the government’s continued policy on 
investment  incentives.  Various  fees  are  to  be  rationalized.  With  regards  to  tax  administration, 
tax self assessment will be further expanded, with the General Department of Taxation adopting 
a  functionally-based  organizational  structure  focusing  on  taxpayer  education  and  service,  tax 
audit and inspection, and computerization of tax administration.  
 
15. 
1999  marked  a  turning  point  in  the  size  of  overall  government  spending.  After  steadily 
declining as a ratio of GDP in the preceding years, government spending (excluding onlending, 
carry-over,  and  expenditure  from  retained  revenue)  has  recovered  during  the  period  1999–
2006.  From  a  low  of  21%  of  GDP  in  1999,  it  reached  24.1%  in  2002,  28%  in  2005,  and  had 
increased to over 31% in 2006. Between 1999 and 2006, total government spending rose at the 
remarkable  average  annual  rate  of  16  percent  in  nominal  terms,  with  capital  expenditure 
growing  at  some  20%.  As  a  share  of  GDP,  current  expenditure  rose  from  13.8%  in  1999  to 
19.3% in 2006, while capital expenditure rose from 5.7% to 9.1% over the same period. Capital 
expenditure has averaged 30% of total expenditure over the last three years. 
 
The  net  result  of  these  revenue  and  expenditure  trends  has  been  a  budget  deficit  that 
16. 
has remained manageable, ranging between 1.1% and 2.8% over  the period 1999–2006. The 
National  Assembly  has  been  prudent  in  stipulating  that  the  budget  deficit  plus  amortization 
should  not  exceed  5%  of  GDP.  The  revenues  collected  by  the  government  fully  financed 

 Appendix 2 

39 

recurrent expenditure and partly financed capital expenditure. Thus, borrowing was undertaken 
only to finance, and was always less than, capital expenditure.  
 
17. 
By the end of 2006, the government debt that is attributable to budgetary expenditures, 
including  ODA  onlending,  stands  at  around  37%  of  GDP.  However,  to  get  a  more  complete 
picture  of  the  wider  public  debt  position  it  is  important  to  add  items  that  are  currently  not 
reflected in the budget. Two such items are bonds issued to finance certain infrastructure and 
education  projects  and  the  recapitalization  costs  of  state-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCBs). 
Their  inclusion  in  public  debt  numbers  is  likely  to  raise  its  level  by  about  3  percentage  points. 
This is by no means an alarming level, but it would be prudent to be watchful of these trends. 
 

2. 

Fiscal Transparency 

 
18. 
Fiscal  transparency  plays  an  important  role  in  ensuring  fiscal  sustainability.  Fiscal 
transparency  enables  accountability  to  citizens  regarding  the  use  of  government  finances  and 
the  quality  of  fiscal  management,  and  facilitates  the  monitoring  conducted  by  government 
agencies,  social  organizations  and  grassroot  communities  of  the  allocation  and  spending  of 
public  resources  by  national  and  subnational  governments.  As  well  as  encouraging 
sustainability, this can enhance the effectiveness of public financial management. 
 
19. 
Viet  Nam  has  made  continuous  efforts  since  1997  to  enhance  fiscal  transparency  and 
publicity. These efforts have followed two tracks. The first is announcement of policies regarding 
allocation  norms,  expenditure  norms,  fiscal  assignments  and  monitoring  arrangements.  The 
second  is  the  publication  and  dissemination  of  figures,  data  and  materials  relating  to  annual 
budget  planning  and  final  accounts  of  the  state  budget  at  all  levels  of  government  and  at 
spending unit level.  
 
20. 
In  1998  the  budget  revenue  and  expenditure  figures  were  published  in  the  General 
Statistics  Office’s  Statistical  Yearbook  for  the  first  time.  In  the  same  year,  Viet  Nam’s  State 
Budget revenues and expenditures were published in the IMF’s Government Finance Statistics 
Yearbook, also for the first time. Decision 192 on Fiscal Transparency was issued by the Prime 
Minister  in  2004,  specifying  the  rules  of  fiscal  transparency  and  publication.  The  requirements 
for disclosure have been substantially increased. In particular, allocation norms approved by the 
National  Assembly  and  the  people’s  councils  must  be  publicized  at  each  budget  level. 
Organizations  funded  from  the  state  budget  must  disclose  their  state  budget  support,  budget 
plans  and  final  accounts,  and  the  methods  used  to  determine  their  state  budget  support.  For 
state  capital  investment  projects,  annual  budget  allocations,  budget  plans,  final  accounts  and 
bidding results for procurements must be disclosed. 
 

3. 

Pro-Poor Public Expenditures 

 
21. 
Viet Nam is committed to a strategy of poverty reduction. Astonishing progress has been 
made.  Over  the  period  1993–2002,  the  proportion  of  people  below  the  poverty  line  has  fallen 
from 58% to 29%, and the Government estimates that the proportion fell to 26% in 2004. Thus, 
Viet Nam has lifted approximately 25 million people out of poverty in less than a decade. Public 
expenditure allocation has played an important role in this achievement.

22. 
Assessing  the  extent  to  which  public  spending  is  resulting  in  a  transfer  of  resources 
towards  poor  households  requires  consideration  of  both  the  composition  of  public expenditure 
and the effectiveness of public spending within each sector. It is clear, however, that pro-poor 
budget  allocations  are  an  important  step  towards  pro-poor  service  delivery.  The  Government 
has  three  important  tools  for  public  spending  and  poverty  reduction  allocation.  The  first  is 
budget transfers, with statistics showing that poor provinces generally received substantial net 
transfers per capita from the central level. The second is the allocation of state investment, with 
evidence indicating that investment-related resources are skewed toward the richest programs. 
It can be argued that capital expenditures are more “pro-growth”, and that in the long term, the 
resulting  economic  growth  will  benefit  the  poor.  The  third  are  National  Target  Programs.  The 
budget  for  targeted  programs  increased  at  an  average  rate  of  25%  over  the  last  three  years, 
higher  than  the  16%  growth  in  total  expenditure,  reflecting  the  fact  that  more  resources  have 
been allocated for pro-poor programs.  
 

4. 

Towards PRSC 7 

 
23. 
Looking forward, the World Bank and PRSC stakeholders have considered several key 
reform policies for PRSC 7 in support of the Government’s implementation of SEDP 2006–2010. 
These key policies are distilled from SEDP 2006–2010, the joint-donor annual analytical report, 
VDR  2007,  and  continuing  policy  dialogue  during  the  loan  fact-finding  (upgraded  to  appraisal) 
mission.  These  key  or  priority  policies,  referred  as  triggers  by  the  World  Bank’s  program 
document, are not binding conditions, but rather  serve as a guide to focus the policy dialogue 
towards PRSC 7.  
 
24. 
The  key  policies  that  PRSC  stakeholders  will  focus  on  in  the  coming  year  include 
policies related to early warning mechanisms to address impacts of World Trade Organization 
accession;  the  lending  policy  of  economic  groups;  participation  of  strategic  partners  in  the 

 Appendix 2 

41 

equitization of SOCBs;  cost norms systems in the civil works market; tuition fees at secondary 
and  tertiary  levels;  health  insurance  premiums;  voluntary  pension  program  for  farmers  and 
informal  sector;  guidelines  for  the  Gender  Equality  Law;  forest  development;  integrated  river 
basin management and the national sanitation strategy; criteria for selecting public investment 
projects; disclosure of State Audit of Viet Nam reports; and asset declaration by senior officials.  
 
The World Bank will assess progress on these key policies towards the end of 2007 in 
25. 
order to launch formal preparation for PRSC 7. Given that these key policies spread across all 
four pillars of the program, uneven progress may be expected. As a result, such assessment will 
be holistic, recognizing that some triggers may not be fully met, while the expected targets may 
be exceeded in other areas.

Appendix 3 

INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND LETTER OF ASSESSMENT 1 

 
1.       Vietnam’s  economic  performance  has  remained  strong  during  the  first  few  months  of 
2007.  Exports  have  continued  to  grow  briskly,  investment  and  consumption  growth  have 
remained  strong,  and  industrial production has continued  to  expand  at double-digit  rates.  With 
market  sentiment  bolstered  by  Vietnam’s  much-awaited  accession  to  the  WTO  on  January  11, 
foreign direct investment (FDI) and portfolio capital inflows have been particularly buoyant, and 
the overall balance of payments has recorded a sizable surplus. 

2.       Growing  access  to  foreign  markets  and  capital  has  created  new  opportunities  for  cost-
effective  financing  of  Vietnam’s  large  investment  requirements,  but  has  also  created  new 
challenges. The Ho Chi Minh City Stock Market Price Index rose by 144.5 percent in 2006, and 
by  another  50  percent  in  the  first  two  months  of  2007,  before  retreating  somewhat  in  recent 
months.  With  the  number  of  listed  companies  rising  from  41  at  end-2005  to  nearly  200,  the 
market’s total capitalization soared from less that VND 10 trillion (1.2 percent of GDP) at end-
2005 to VND 320 trillion (28 ½ percent of GDP) as of mid-May 2007. This unprecedented boom 
in stock prices has reduced the cost of capital for firms, boosted the wealth and consumption of 
domestic  investors,  and  increased  Vietnam’s  appeal  to  foreign  investors.  At  the  same  time, 
however,  the  need  to  contain  the  attendant  risks  to  the  financial  system  has  heightened  the 
urgency  of  policy  measures  to  protect  macroeconomic  stability,  enhance  financial  system 
surveillance, and improve the governance of state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) and state-
owned enterprises (SOE). 

(i)  Short-Term Outlook and Risks 

3.       The prospects for 2007 remain broadly favorable. GDP is projected to continue to expand 
at an annual rate of around 8 percent, led by sustained export and investment growth. While a 
pick-up in imports is projected to shift the trade balance back into a deficit, this is likely to be 
more than financed by continued strong receipts from remittances and capital inflows.  

4.       However,  the  outlook  is  not  without  risks.  Inflation  remains  stubbornly  high,  with  the 
twelve-month  rate  estimated  to  have  risen  back  above  7  percent  since  April  2007.  Welcome 
adjustments  in  electricity  and  petroleum  prices,  together  with  a  resurfacing  of  food  supply 
shocks, have contributed to the recent uptick in prices. However, large increases in the prices of 
major nonfood items also seem to point to growing demand pressures, which may become more 
difficult  to  contain  as  growing  capital  inflows  complicate  monetary  management.  The  risk  of 
rising inflation could be heightened if a large positive fiscal impulse were to further add to the 
demand pressures in 2007.

economic situation provided to the Consultative Group (CG) Meeting held in Hanoi on 14-15 December 
2006. The IMF noted that this letter is identical to the IMF staff statement presented at the midterm CG 
meeting in Halong on 1 June 2007, and has also been used by the World Bank for the PRSC operation 
considered by the World Bank's Board of Directors on 21 June 2007. 

 

 Appendix 3 

43 

5.       Over  the  medium  term,  a  slowdown  in  the  global  economy  or  a  tightening  of  global 
liquidity conditions could expose vulnerabilities in the balance sheets of financial institutions and 
large  SOEs,  which  may  have  made  sub-optimal  investment  decisions  during  the  period  of 
booming  demand.  The  resulting  contingent  government  liabilities,  together  with  continued 
reliance on the state sector to finance the bulk of the country’s huge infrastructure needs, could 
eventually threaten debt sustainability. 

(ii) Fiscal Policy and Reforms   

6.       The  risk  of  inflation  and  the  need  to  protect  medium-term  debt  sustainability  call  for  a 
more cautious  fiscal stance. The estimated fiscal deficit recorded a welcome decrease in 2006, 
but the 2007 Budget appears to be set on an expansionary course. Current expenditure is to be 
boosted by a sharp increase in social expenditures in 2007, after having been fueled largely by 
increasing  wages  and  oil  subsidies  in  2005–06.  While  a  large  oil  revenue  windfall  helped  to 
contain the overall deficit (based on the Fund’s definition, which includes on-lending through the 
Vietnam Development Bank (VDB) and off-budget investment) to less than 4 percent of GDP in 
2006,  full  implementation  of  the  investment  plans  envisaged  in  the  Socio-Economic 
Development  Program  (SEDP)  for  2006–2010  could  raise  the  deficit  to  7 percent  of  GDP  in 
2007. The non-oil deficit would rise from 13½ percent of GDP in 2006 to 15½ percent of GDP 
in  2007,  while  the  public  debt  stock  would  rise  from  about  44 percent  of  GDP  at  end-2006  to 
around  46  percent  of  GDP  by  end-2007.  While  the  concessional  terms  on  most  external  debt, 
which  still  accounts  for  more  than  half  of  total  public  debt,  would  help  keep  the  debt  service 
burden  manageable,  growing  recourse  to  market-based  financing  through  the  capital  markets 
could make the fiscal position more vulnerable to changes in market sentiment. 

7.       Given the projected leveling off of oil receipts, the containment of the fiscal deficit will 
require a concerted effort to boost non-oil revenues and curb expenditure growth. The reduction 
in import tariff rates associated with WTO accession, and the constraints posed by planned tax 
reforms, call for an accelerated effort to improve tax administration. On the expenditure side, we 
welcome  the  recent  progress  toward  adjusting  domestic  oil  prices,  and  support  the  authorities’ 
decision to remove remaining controls over oil prices by the end of 2008. To curb pressures on 
the  government’s  wage  bill  and  slow  the  growth  of  its  pension  liabilities,  we  encourage  the 
authorities to discontinue the indexation of public wages and pensions to the common minimum 
wage, and adopt instead a more differentiated and merit-based structure of salary increases in the 
context  of  civil  service  reform.  Slowing  the  growth  of  public  investment  is  likely  to  be  a 
challenge,  given  the  urgent  need  to  ease  the  country’s  serious  infrastructure  bottlenecks.  To 
ensure  continued  development  of  essential  public  infrastructure,  more  proactive  steps  to 
encourage private participation could be considered. Projects still funded through the issuance of 
investment bonds or on-lending should be subject to rigorous screening and monitoring, and the 
credit  appraisal  and  risk  management  capacities  of  the  Vietnam  Development  Bank  (VDB) 
strengthened. Effective enforcement of the new laws to curb corruption and prevent the waste of 
public funds would need to be an integral part of this effort. 

(iii) Monetary Policy and Exchange System Reform 

8.       A more restrained monetary policy will likely be required to contain inflation, and limit 
the  potential  expansion  of  nonperforming  loans  (NPLs).  Credit  growth  has  showed  signs  of 

 

 44 

Appendix 3 

reacceleration in recent months, with the rate of growth of credit to the economy rising from 23 
percent in the year to September 2006 to about 29 percent in the year to February 2007. While 
the authorities’ monetary program for 2007 envisages a slowing of credit growth to 20 percent 
by year-end, the achievement of this objective is threatened by ample excess bank liquidity. The 
authorities’ recent efforts to introduce prudential restraints on commercial bank lending for stock 
market purchases are welcome steps, which should help reduce banks’ exposure to stock market 
risks and guard against a potentially costly boom-bust cycle in stock prices. The authorities also 
need  to  take  more  pro-active  measures  to  mop  up  excess  liquidity,  including  by  allowing  the 
State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) to exercise adequate autonomy in the issuance of SBV bills.  

9.       Vietnam’s  rapid  integration  into  the  global  economy  calls  for  continued  efforts  to 
increase  exchange  rate  flexibility.  The  authorities  have  recently  taken  welcome  steps  in  this 
direction. In January 2007, the trading band of the dong vis-à-vis the U.S. dollar was widened 
from +/-0.25 percent to +/-0.5 percent around the daily reference rate set by the SBV, and the 
dong  temporarily  appreciated  as  the  pace  of  inflows  peaked  in  January-February  2007.  In  the 
face  of  continuing  large  foreign  exchange  inflows,  further  steps  to  increase  exchange  rate 
flexibility would serve to stem inflationary pressures while decreasing the need for sterilization. 
A  more  flexible  exchange  rate  policy  could  also  mitigate  the  potential  disruptive  effects  of  a 
possible  future  reversal  of  capital  inflows  by  encouraging  economic  agents  to  better  hedge 
exchange rate risks and allowing the exchange rate to play a greater role as a shock absorber.   
 
Bank Reform and Financial Sector Supervision 
 
10.       Bank  reform  remains  key  to  improving  the  allocation  of  saving  and  investment  and 
protecting financial stability. The growing possibilities for financing through the capital market, 
increasing  competition  from  joint-stock  banks,  and  the  new  regime  of  liberal  entry  of  fully 
foreign-owned  banks,  have  increased  the  urgency  of  SOCB  reform.  In  this  context,  the 
government’s  renewed  commitment  to  proceed  with  the  equitization  of  the  main  SOCBs  is 
welcome,  as  is  the  recent  increase  in  the  ceiling  for  participation  by  individual  strategic 
investors.  We  also  welcome  the  recent  adoption  of  an  SOCB  recapitalization  plan,  and  look 
forward  to  the  upcoming  publication  of  financial  reports  of  the  SOCBs  based  on  International 
Accounting Standards. These steps need to be backed by timely action to improve the corporate 
governance of SOCBs, including by providing their managers with adequate autonomy to make 
lending decisions based on purely commercial criteria.  
  
11.       The growing scope for securities market operations and portfolio capital movements also 
calls  for  further  steps  to  strengthen  prudential  regulation  of  bank  and  nonbank  financial 
institutions. We  support the  authorities’  medium-term  plans to  convert  the  SBV  into a  modern 
central bank, and to grant it adequate authority and independence to carry out an anti-inflationary 
monetary policy and effective financial sector supervision. In the meantime, it is important that 
the  SBV,  the  State  Securities  Commission  (SSC),  and  the  Ministry  of  Finance  improve  the 
tracking  of  vulnerabilities  associated  with  stock  market-related  risks  and  capital  movements. 
Given  the  risks posed by  related  transactions  among banks,  their  securities  company  affiliates, 
and  the  buyers  or  issuers  of  securities,  a  concerted  effort  is  required  to  regulate  stock  market-
related  credit  and  discourage  insider  trading.  Controls  also  need  to  be  put  in  place  to  prohibit 
related-party transactions within economic groups involved in a mix of industrial operations and 
financial services. 

 Appendix 3 

45 

 
State-Owned Enterprise Reform and Private Sector Development 
 
12.       The  authorities’  plans  to  restructure  and  equitize  SOEs  are  welcome.  However,  it  will 
also be important that SOE managers be granted clear incentives and full autonomy to make their 
own  pricing  and  investment  decisions  on  commercial  principles,  and  the  entry  of  foreign 
strategic  investors  should  be  encouraged  to  facilitate  the  needed  improvement  in  SOE 
governance.  The  mandates  of  economic  groups  of  wholly  state-owned  enterprises,  and  their 
relations  with  government,  should  be  clearly  defined,  and  regulatory  safeguards  established, 
where needed, to ensure that their market power will not be used to undermine competition. 
 
13.       A more transparent and market-friendly legal and regulatory framework would be key to 
enabling Vietnam to capitalize on its growing appeal to foreign investors. We welcome plans to 
align energy prices with world market conditions, and urge the authorities to also remove other 
remaining  price  controls  that  discourage  private  investment.  To  further  level  the  playing  field, 
simplify rules and regulations, and improve the business climate, we encourage the authorities to 
swiftly  adopt  pending  legislation  and  associated  implementing  decrees  and  circulars  in  full 
conformity with Vietnam’s WTO commitments. 
 
14.       The  quality,  timeliness,  and  dissemination  of  macroeconomic  statistics  and  Financial 
Stability Indicators will also need to be improved to support informed policy decisions and build 
enduring  investor  confidence.  In  this  regard,  we  support  the  authorities’  ongoing  efforts  to 
develop better measures of core inflation and look forward to the issuance of the government’s 
first  semi-annual  Debt  Bulletin.  More  transparent  accounting,  reporting,  and  monitoring  of  the 
government’s extra-budgetary operations and all publicly-funded projects would also be helpful 
in reassuring donors that their assistance is being put to the best use. 
 
Concluding Remarks 
 
15.       Vietnam’s  historic  accession  to  the  WTO  attests  to  its  impressive  economic  progress 
since  the  launching  of  the  policy  of  Doi  Moi  some  twenty  years  ago.  In  the  coming  years, 
deepening economic and financial integration should facilitate achievement of the government’s 
ambitious objectives to lift Vietnam from the ranks of low-income countries by 2010 and join the 
ranks of industrial countries by 2020. However, growing exposure to global markets has made it 
all the more important that macroeconomic policies be kept on a sound footing and the pace of 
market-oriented reforms accelerated. We have no doubt that, with the continued good judgment 
of  its leadership, Vietnam will successfully meet these challenges, and we wish the authorities 
every success in these endeavors.

47-49 Ly Thai To Street, Hanoi, Vietnam
